name: No Man's - Prepare to Sky Edition (PTSd) -- A Progression-Difficulty-Balance Overhaul
summary: A balance overhaul to achieve 5 things: improve difficulty (mostly optional now), balance rewards away from passive options towards a variety of active playstyles, make the choice between weapons/starships/multi-tools more distinct and meaningful, slow down progression to stretch out the early-mid game, and a few bug fixes and new features.
author: Xen0nex
description:
[center][size=6]No Man's - [b]P[/b]repare [b]T[/b]o [b]S[/b]ky E[b]d[/b][/size][size=6]ition
[/size](PTSd)[/center]
[size=2]The title is [i]mostly [/i]a joke: while by default PTSd does attempt to substantially increase the challenge of combat, exploration, trading, farming, etc. while reducing many "overpowered" income options, you can reduce most of that back down with the in-game Difficulty Settings. Even with the default settings, a number of activities / rewards / costs are actually improved from vanilla, such as Settlement rewards, the loot from most exploration activities, Class upgrade/Pet unlock prices, larger Refiner stacksizes, etc. And much of the mod is not centered around difficulty at all, but instead on improving balance or adding new options.[/size]

[size=5][center][b]Goals of this mod[/b][/center][/size]
If you enjoy [b]starting new save files[/b], the [b]sense of progression [/b]of a [b]new character[/b] through the [b]early & middle portions of the game[/b], and start to lose interest once your character has [b]unlocked everything[/b] and can do anything easily, and prefer [b]choices[/b] without[b] overpowered or underwhelming options[/b], PTSd may interest you. Covering many aspects of the game through a wide range of [b]cost/value/reward adjustments, rebalanced equipment stats, improved enemy combat stats, [/b]and[b] a few added features[/b], PTSd aims to:
[b]
[/b][list]
[*]Remove or restrict most "[b]overpowered[/b]" get-rich quick schemes, such as market crashing, chlorine refining, Activated Indium mines, scrapping Interceptor ships, etc.
[/list][list]
[*][b]Stretch out the early & mid-game[/b] so the player is not able to immediately buy any & everything. Generally there will be more time where the player can be "looking forward" to unlocking various tech or features that are currently unavailable or unaffordable.
[/list][list]
[*]Make buying & [b]using weaker C Class ships or upgrade modules[/b] early on more appealing, as the higher class items should be expensive enough to prevent the player from simply always just buying the highest quality options available.
[/list][list]
[*]Make it [b]more rewarding[/b] when the player eventually is able to get higher class starships / multi-tools or better exocraft, or invest upgrades into them, especially since enemies / the environment are challenging enough to appreciate the added ease / convenience they bring. Generally there will be a more noticeable gap between the performance of a fresh Class C piece of equipment, and a maxed out Class S full of upgrades.
[/list][list]
[*]Increase the base [b]challenge [/b]of most [b]combat encounters[/b] (can largely be offset with various combat-related in-game Difficulty Settings)
[/list][list]
[*]As much as possible, avoid situations where either [b]one playstyle is so clearly superior[/b] to the alternatives that they aren't worth considering, or the inverse where an [b]option is completely underwhelming[/b] compared to others. For example, in Vanilla an Activated Indium mine or Fusion Ignitor farm are orders of magnitude more profitable than any other activity, while conversely Settlements, salvaging Crashed Freighters, or rescuing Freighters from pirates typically provide so little reward that it is hard to justify the time taken to do them. In PTSd the rewards of many activities are more comparable, although they each still have advantages or disadvantages.
[/list][list]
[*]Relatedly, in general reduce the gap between "[b]passive[/b]" forms of income such as [b]Extractors/Farms/Frigate Expeditions[/b] and "[b]active[/b]" income such as [b]exploring, finding & selling valuables, destroying spaceships, completing space station missions[/b], etc. so that "passive" income doesn't completely overshadow "active" income, and "active" play is encouraged more.
[/list][list]
[*]Similarly, differentiate & balance the Multi-Tool / Starship [b]weapons [/b]and [b]Multi-Tools[/b] / [b]Starships [/b]themselves so that there is no "[b]clear winner[/b]" which is statistically superior to all the others. E.G. Why pick the Neutron Cannon when the Scatter Blaster kills everything much quicker? Or why pick a Hauler when you can upgrade an Exotic to just as much storage with excellent stats? Or why pick a Royal/Experimental/Pistol when an Alien Multi-Tool has higher Damage (which also improves mining speed), and the Scan stats provide negligible benefits? In PTSd the various kinds of equipment and weapons are both made more distinct from each other with more noticeable differences in speed, abilities, etc. while still making sure each has a specialty or niche that makes it worthwhile. For example, the [b]Mining [/b]and [b]Scan [/b]stats for [b]Multi-Tools[/b] now directly improve the resources / units you receive when mining/scanning things.
[/list][list]
[*]Add more ways of [b]steadily earning Nanites[/b] throughout the game.
[/list][list]
[*]Add more ways of obtaining [b]Tritium,[/b] [b]Di-Hydrogen[/b] & [b]Salvaged Data[/b] to the mid/late game.
[/list][list]
[*]Correct some [b]Vanilla bugs[/b] such as the Ship Agility stat only affect maneuverability while boosting, or supercharged slots making the mining laser/scanner tech slower instead of faster, or mining speed being affected by both the Mining and Damage stat bonuses on your Multi-Tool, or certain items / effects having typos in their values making them far stronger/weaker than intended, etc.
[/list][list]
[*]When possible, clarify unintuitive vanilla mechanics or PTSd changes that are particularly important with [b]expanded descriptions[/b] on techs/items/buildings/Difficulty Settings (see bottom of the [b]Customization [/b]section below on how to make these PTSd changes to vanilla in-game text display on computers set to languages other than [b]English[/b]).
[/list]

[b][size=5][center]Changes Made & Reasoning[/center][/size][/b]
The individual changes made are too many to list, but here is the "[b]bullet point[/b]" version for reference (which can be searched through with [b]ctrl-f[/b] after opening all the [b]Spoiler[/b] tags), along with the gameplay reasons for how they help achieve the [b]goals [/b]above. Note that many of these changes are designed to [b]work together[/b], E.G. player starship shields are increased, but enemy ship damage and groups are increased even more. The actual individual value changes made to the game can be seen within the [b].lua files[/b] for the mod.
[size=2][b]Note[/b]: Unless explicitly stated otherwise, any changes in the rest of the [b]Description [/b]below listing a multiplier, such as "increased by [b]2.5x[/b]" or "reduced to [b]0.8x,[/b]" means that value is now equal to ([b]2.5[/b] x [the vanilla value]) or ([b]0.8[/b] x [the vanilla value]), while changes in the [b]Changelog [/b]above are in reference to the previous PTSd values.[/size]

[b][size=3]Progression Changes[/size][/b]
[spoiler]
[list]
[*]All [b]upgrade modules[/b] for all kinds of equipment can now be installed [b]5x[/b] times instead of [b]3x[/b] times, though their strength has been adjusted so that when "maxed out" the equipment should be roughly as powerful as in the pre-Waypoint version of PTSd. This was done so it will take more time / Nanites to find enough good upgrade modules to "max out" your equipment, and to make Tech slots more valuable as you will have more things to install.
[*]Thanks to an adaptation of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/933?tab=description]Lo2k's New Milestones[/url]﻿, ﻿most [b]Milestones [/b]now have [b]substantially higher requirements[/b] to achieve each rank, and additionally the [b]total overall number of milestones needed[/b] to progress through the stages of the [b]Atlas Path[/b] questline are also increased. The final rank for most milestones has significantly higher requirements than the previous rank, although you can still reach Overall Rank "[b]Magellan[/b]" to complete the Atlas Path without reaching any of the final ranks for any of the milestones.
[*]Related to this, more [b]game progression[/b] is now tied to the [b]Milestone system[/b], as nearly [b]~60 techs/buildables[/b] now [b]require [/b]either various [b]Atlas Seeds[/b] or resources which now require a particular Atlas Seed to obtain (However you can "[b]skip[/b]" these requirements by temporarily setting the [b]Crafting Requirements[/b] setting in the Difficulty menu to "[b]Free[/b]"). These are an assortment of techs & buildables that are especially [b]game-changing[/b] or [b]render other options obsolete[/b], which are now effectively [b]"locked" out[/b] of obtaining in the first few hours of the game as you will need enough [b]Milestones [/b]to unlock the appropriate [b]Atlas Seed recipe[/b](These tech can also no longer be found pre-installed on "wild" starships or Multi-Tools). The vast majority of them require one of the first 6 Atlas Seeds, so after getting [b]48 Milestones[/b] you should have access to almost all tech / buildables. Some notable examples:
[*]﻿ ○ The [b]specialised hyperdrive techs[/b] required to visit [b]Red/Green/Blue/Purple stars[/b] to obtain their corresponding unique metals are locked behind the [b]1st, 3rd, [/b][b]5th, & 6th Atlas Seed[/b] ([b]8 / 24 / 40 / 48 Milestones[/b]). Thus, any items requiring [b]Cadmium [/b]/ [b]Emeril [/b]/ [b]Indium / Quartzite (or Lithium or Crystallised Helium) [/b]are likewise locked behind those Milestone requirements. 
[*] ﻿ ﻿○ All [b]Exocraft Geobays[/b] require either [b]Cadmium [/b]or [b]Emeril [/b]to construct, so you must first visit a Red star system to begin using exocraft
[*] ﻿ ﻿﻿○ [b]Large Refiners[/b] & Freighter [b]Refiner Rooms[/b] now require [b]Emeril [/b]to build. However the Colossus' [b]Mineral Processing Rig[/b] can be made without it, making it an option for earlier access to the more complex refining recipes
[*] ○ The [b]Survey Device[/b] tech required for finding [b]power / mineral / gas hotspots[/b] in order to use the corresponding [b]automated extractors[/b] is locked behind [b]Indium[/b].  The PTSd-buffed [b]AMU [/b]/ [b]Atmosphere Harvesters[/b] may be useful for longer now.
[*] ﻿ ﻿○ Many of the more powerful [b]exocraft Radar techs[/b] which can [b]locate [/b]desirable planetary locations are locked behind [b]Indium[/b], making planetary charts useful for longer
[*] ﻿ ﻿ ﻿﻿○ Both the [b]Minotaur Radar Array[/b] and [b]High-Power Sonar[/b] for the [b]Nautilon [/b]have been split[b] [/b]into a [b]core tech[/b] & separate "[b]upgrade tech[/b]", the same as how the other vehicular Exocraft Radar techs work. This way the ability to search for valuable locations like Crashed Starships & Freighters can remain [b]locked [/b]behind [b]Quartzite [/b]with the "upgrade tech", while the simpler locations and ability to scan for nearby plants & resource nodes is [b]available earlier[/b] with the "core tech".
[*] ○ The various [b]Exocraft techs[/b] which fully protect against a [b]specific Hazard[/b] are now locked behind [b]Indium[/b], making hazard management & the Minotaur more important for longer. (As in vanilla, Exocraft still naturally slow down Hazard drain by 3x while inside them)
[*] ﻿ ﻿○ The [b]Aqua-Jets[/b] tech for landing on water now requires [b]Quartzite[/b], so that the Nautilon remains useful for longer.
[*] ﻿ ﻿○ The techs which allow "[b]free fuel recharging[/b]" for [b]exocraft / starships[/b] now are locked behind [b]Crystallised Helium[/b][b] / 7th Atlas Seed[/b]. (﻿Living Ships can still gain Chloroplast Membrane tech at any point from Psychonic Eggs.)
[*] ﻿○ The [b]Trade Rocket[/b] costs [b]4x Dark Matter[/b] to build, making it a mid-game tech. It also costs 8x as much Tritium to recharge.
[*] ﻿ ﻿○ The [b]Matter Beam[/b] tech for the [b]Freighter [/b]requires [b]16[/b] of the [b]final Atlas Seed[/b] to build in addition to [b]16 [/b]Salvaged Frigate Modules (or temporarily setting the Crafting Costs setting to "Free"), as it effectively eliminates the entire inventory management aspect of the game.
[*]As most missions, including the Atlas Path, are unavailable in [b]Abandoned Mode[/b], opening some of the small boxes in [b]Abandoned space stations[/b] in [b]Abandoned Mode[/b] has a small chance to teach you the next unknown [b]Atlas Seed recipe[/b], in order from 1 - 10 (Atlas Seed descriptions now note this). On average you should learn one for every ~5 stations you visit & loot, so on average it will require visiting around [b]~50 Abandoned Stations[/b] to learn all 10 Atlas Seed recipes in [b]Abandoned Mode[/b].
[*]Similarly, opening boxes on Abandoned space stations in Abandoned Mode will teach you the recipe for an [b]Abandoned Mode-only [/b]Exosuit tech, [b]Discordant Key[/b], which while installed grants access to Discordant Interfaces at Korvax Monoliths to obtain [b]Atlantid Multi-Tools[/b]. For [b]existing Abandoned Mode saves[/b], the next Buried Cache or Crashed Freighter Cargo Pod Container you open should contain the recipe. The Discordant Key requires a Korvax Casing, Living Glass, and some Polished Stone so it won't be buildable right away. 
[*]Re-ordered which [b]Atlas Seeds[/b] require which substances to craft, so that anytime a new color of star system becomes accessible, crafting the next Atlas Seed requires stellar metal from that color star (except for purple stars). This should allow fewer techs/items to be crafted "out of sequence" in save-games where all Atlas Seed recipes were already unlocked.
[*]To prevent heavy "sequence breaking" of the various things locked behind Cadmium/Emeril/Indium, or acquiring an S Class starship too early on, crafting the Consciousness Bridge at the start of the [b]Starbirth mission[/b] for getting the [b]Living Ship[/b] now requires [b]Emeril[/b]. This still allows some leeway in making use of the Living Ship's hyperdrive tech as a "shortcut" from Emeril to Indium, depending on how soon you complete the Starbirth Mission compared to gaining more Milestones.
[*]Similarly, various starship procedural upgrades now use [b]Chromatic Metal[/b] instead of [b]Cadmium[/b] to repair. This prevents players from buying & dismantling them to get early access to Cadmium.
[*]The player [b]starts a new game[/b] with [b]fewer slots[/b] in their [b]Multi-Tool,[/b] [b]Starship[/b], and [b]Exosuit Tech[/b] inventory. Also, a special damaged slot has been added to the starting Multi-Tool to explain that it is weak and can never have Damage/Mining/Scanning stat bonuses like all other multi-tools can. (This is also true in vanilla)
[*]When starting a [b]new game[/b] with the [b]Tutorial enabled[/b], the [b]Creature Pellets recipe[/b] is given at the same time as the Hermetic Seal recipe. So while the initial trip to & from your crashed ship still needs to be done on foot, you can potentially ride a companion for the second walk back to your crashed ship and other trips you'll need to make before reaching the Anomaly. These are also useful to distract any hostile predators you encounter during early missions, as you can repeatedly throw them on the ground with a hotkey or feed them to hostile predators directly to calm them down.
[*]Similarly in [b]Abandoned Mode[/b], instead of it being unavailable you can now learn the "by hand" [b]Creature Pellet[/b] recipe from either the next Buried Cache or Abandoned Station box you open if not yet known, or unlocked from the base building unlock tree in the Construction Research Unit/Station.
[*]Meeting the first of [b]Apollo's contacts[/b] at a Space Station no longer immediately teaches you the [b]Roamer Geobay recipe[/b]. To learn it you can either progress the [b]Base Computer Archives[/b] mission chain far enough, house the [b]Exocraft Technician NPC[/b] at your base, or purchase it yourself at the Anomaly if you want it sooner.
[*]The [b]Scientist NPC[/b] now teaches the [b]Medium Refiner[/b] recipe instead of the [b]Large Refiner[/b].
[*]The "[b]Expanding the Base[/b]" mission and its sub-missions have had the items required to hand-in to complete each step increased by [b]20x [/b]for substances and [b]10x [/b]for (most) Products. Since these missions award many useful techs, it should now be harder to power through them all right away.
[*]While the recipes for all 10 [b]Storage Container[/b] blueprints are normally awarded early on in the base building mission chain by the Overseer, now you will only receive the [b]first 3 recipes[/b]. The other 7 recipes must be purchased with Salvaged Data at the Anomaly at increasingly higher prices (up to [b]4x[/b] the normal cost for the final 10th recipe). Similarly, only the first [b]Freighter Storage Room[/b] recipe is given for free and no Corvette Cargo Rack recipes are known by default, so the others can be purchased for 1 Salvaged Data at the [b]Anomaly [/b]after unlocking the corresponding Container recipe. However, Cargo Racks cost the same amount of Salvaged Data as the corresponding Storage Container to unlock.
[*]In particular for the [b]Corvette Cargo Racks[/b], increased the construction cost of Cargo Racks significantly, they now require [b]5 Metal Plating[/b], and [b]3 Recycled Circuitry[/b] in place of Microprocessors to build, and also added increasingly higher-tier [b]stellar metals[/b] (Cadmium, Emeril, etc.) or [b]Atlas Seeds[/b] (State Phasure, Novae Reclaiment, etc.) as an ingredient for each of them. (The extra stellar metal / Atlas Seed requirements can be removed in "PTSd Product + Crafting Rebalance.lua" by searching for "Cargo Racks"). These changes should mean that adding 1 or 2 Cargo Racks to a Corvette is still doable early on, but matching the full storage access of a freighter or base will only be possible late-game and will be significantly more expensive. Also, Added an optional [b]CorvStorageBuildable [/b]toggle in [b]gBase Items BasicX.lua[/b] to completely disallow building Corvette Cargo Racks at all, if desired.
[*][b]Large Hydroponics Tray[/b] no longer automatically unlocked by the Farmer NPC, must be purchased at a reduced cost at the Anomaly instead
[*]Removed [b]Conflict Scanner[/b] and all starship/multi-tool [b]weapon techs[/b] except for Pulse Spitter, Plasma Launcher, and Phase Beam from the [b]random tech reward pools[/b]. In exchange, added more low-level "[b]utility[/b]" techs to the random tech reward pools such as Simple Translator, Shield Lattice, Personal Refiner, Emergency Warp Unit, Instability Engine, etc. In PTSd these random tech rewards mostly come up in the "[b]Expanding the Base[/b]" missions, and default to a related upgrade module instead if you've already learned all the techs.
[*]Similarly, the [b]Armourer NPC[/b] now awards [b]Efficient Thruster[/b] & [b]Ablative Armour[/b] techs alongside a tech from the random ship tech pool instead of the Cyclotron Ballista and Infra-knife Accelerator techs.
[*]To prevent "sequence breaking" the tech tree by getting a Freighter, the Freighter [b]Refiner Room[/b], [b]Galactic Trade Room[/b], and [b]Cultivation Chamber[/b] recipes are no longer known by default but can be [b]unlocked[/b] for 1 [b]Salvaged Frigate Module[/b] (2 for Refiner Room). Their position in the Freighter unlock tree has been adjusted, and they each also have the option to instead be unlocked at the Anomaly for the [b]lower cost[/b] of just 1 (or 2) [b]Salvaged Data[/b] after unlocking their corresponding "planetary" equivalent recipe.
[*]Similarly, the [b]Corvette [/b]Plant Wall and Refiner must be unlocked at the Anomaly in the same locations, and the [b]Corvette [/b]Nutrition Unit requires a Nutrient Processor to construct.
[*]﻿The number of [b]learned alien words[/b] needed to advance each stage of the [b]Base Computer Archives[/b] mission chain has been [b]increased 5x[/b] (vanilla is 3 - 30 words needed for the 10 stages) as words can be learned more quickly in PTSd.
[*]Rewards from the [b]first few Space Station missions[/b] on a new game are now closer to the standard starting rewards, but with 2~3x boosted chance for Exosuit Upgrade Charts, Navigation Data, Salvaged Data, and Multi-Tool Expansion Slots. (As opposed to in vanilla when essentially the only rewards offered are Exosuit Upgrade Charts with a small chance for Multi-Tool Expansion Slots)
[*]The [b]hyperdrive techs[/b] which allow warp access to [b]red, green, & blue[/b] star systems, the [b]Minotaur Geobay[/b] & [b]Exocraft Summoning Station[/b], and the blueprints for [b]Venom Urchin[/b] & [b]Albumen Pearl Orb[/b] are [b]no longer offered as random / mission rewards[/b] (other than the Cadmium Drive from the Armorer in the Expanding the Base quest), and must be purchased instead.
[*][b]Emergency Warp Unit[/b] blueprints now also sold by planetary tech shops such as in (Minor) Settlements / Colossal Archives, not just at the Anomaly. Ingredients also changed to a smaller amount of [b]Silver [/b]instead of Gold, and [b]additional Warp Cells[/b] so the cost to repair it is more accessible early-game.
[*][b]Distress Beacons[/b] at crashed starship crashsites no longer have a chance to teach 1-2 [b]new unknown tech blueprints[/b], and award a related random-Class upgrade module instead.
[*]Certain [b]Traveler [/b]dialogue rewards are [b]half [/b]as likely as vanilla to award a [b]tech-type Memory Fragment[/b] vs. an Inventory-type Memory Fragment or other products.
[*][b]Tech-type Memory Fragments[/b] (mostly from [b]graves [/b]or certain [b]Traveler [/b]dialogue rewards) are now [b]4x [/b]more likely to award [b]procedural upgrades[/b] vs new techs as before. Thus overall, the chance to get a procedural upgrade rather than a packaged tech has gone from around ~33% to ~66%. Also, certain specific techs which had much higher chances than others have been lowered closer to the average chance, so techs awarded are more random
[*]Increase the costs for [b]Tech [/b](between [b]4x~30x[/b] in Nanites), [b]Recipes [/b]([b]10x [/b]in Nanites), and useful [b]Blueprints [/b](Often [b]3x~8x [/b]in Salvaged Data) at the Anomaly & Minor Settlements, etc. This prevents the player from simply buying everything they want right at the start, but instead must save up and choose carefully what will be most useful now. Perhaps you will use the Roamer for a while until you save up the 75 Salvaged Data for a Pilgrim/Minotaur. This also incentivizes completing the various story & basebuilding quests which give tech/blueprints/recipes as rewards.
[*]In exchange, most "[b]non-functional[/b]" base building (e.g. stairs, prefab rooms/corridors, etc.) or [b]decorative[/b] (e.g. posters, "clutter" items, etc.) items which had unlock costs of [b]3~10 Salvaged Data[/b] are reduced down to [b]1~2 Salvaged Data[/b], so that decorating your base does not compete so much with unlocking utility items with special functionality, as those all have greatly increased prices in PTSd.
[*]All types of "[b]Skylight[/b]" Roof panels now require [b]Glass [/b]in place of Ferrite Dust to build
[*]The freighter's [b]Scanner Room[/b] & [b]Orbital Exocraft Materializer[/b] now require either Indium or high-level Atlas Seeds, and take more Salvaged Frigate Modules to unlock. The [b]Scanner Room[/b] now costs [b]2 Navigation Data[/b] to scan a star system, and the Orbital Exocraft Materializer can no longer be unlocked at the Anomaly, only from the freighter bridge now.
[*]Similarly, the [b]Exocraft Summoning Unit[/b] requires the 7th Atlas Seed to craft
[*]Various other functional Freighter tech / rooms also have increased costs more in line with non-freighter versions of those techs / rooms, such as [b]Nutrition Rooms[/b] requiring a Nutrient Processor or [b]Interstellar Scanner[/b] requiring Quad Servos & Pirate Transponders.
[*][b]Increase the costs for higher-class Upgrade Modules[/b], from [b]2.4x to 7.2x[/b] the vanilla price in Nanites for B Class up to S Class (C Class costs [b]1.2x[/b]), with X Class upgrades costing [b]1.8x [/b]vanilla. (C/B/A/S Scanner upgrades additionally cost 1.2x more than other upgrades, however they are less likely to have fewer bonuses than in vanilla) This should encourage buying & using cheap C Class upgrades while saving up for more powerful S Class, which now cost ~[b]40x [/b]more than a C Class, and make X Class mods more appealing. (Note that X Class modules should be sold at any kind of space station to get full value)
[*]The cost for "[b]Evolving[/b]" Living Ship upgrade modules has been increased along the same lines, but each evolution costs only roughly [b]67%[/b] of the price of buying an equivalent regular ship upgrade module.
[*]To balance out the increased nanite value of upgrade modules, the[b] A & S Class upgrades only sell for 0.5x or 0.33x[/b] of their value.
[*]Similarly, while the price for low-inventory C Class starships is a bit higher, maximum-sized inventory C Class starships are [b]roughly twice as expensive[/b], and much like the Upgrade Modules, [b]higher Class Starships increase in cost even faster [/b]than in vanilla, up to [b]4x [/b]or [b]5x [/b]more than C Class for an S Class (Though like with upgrades, starships now have reduced sale/salvage value rate compared to vanilla).
[*] ﻿Most types of starships should now generally follow the same basic pricing curve and use the same Class-based price multipliers, and so should always have the following relationships: [b]Explorers [/b]& [b]Solar [/b]ships cost [b]1x[/b] the "normal" price, [b]Fighters[/b] cost [b]~1.15x[/b] more, [b]Exotics[/b] cost [b]~1.2x[/b] more, and [b]Haulers [/b]cost [b]~0.67x[/b] less on a per-slot basis at all Classes. Living Ship & Sentinel Interceptor values are unchanged as you cannot purchase them directly with units.
[*] ﻿[b]Shuttles [/b]are a special exception, where at C Class and low inventory size they cost [b]~0.5x[/b] as much, but gradually lose their discount at higher Class & inventory size, to where the largest S Class Shuttle costs [b]~0.85x[/b] as much as "normal".
[*] ﻿The price for purchasing inventory slots for a starship have been increased for small ships and decreased for larger ships, so the end result is that it should now generally always be more expensive to buy a smaller starship and then purchase inventory slots for it compared to simply buying a larger starship of the same type & Class to begin with. For S Class ships, on average it should cost ~1.33x as much to obtain a larger starship through inventory expansion compared to buying a larger starship, and even more comparatively expensive at lower classes (costing ~4x as much at C Class).
[*] ﻿Additionally, with the cost of buying small starships increased (to break into components for ship-building) and the max size of "Small" starships reduced (most built starships are usually in the "Small" size category), the expected discount for building an S Class starship compared to buying one should be significantly less. And since the built starship will usually be "Small" in most cases, the money saved by building it will usually eventually be outweighed by the increased cost to purchase inventory slots to bring it up to the size of a "Medium" or "Large" starship.
[*]Freighters mostly follow a similar pattern (costing 3~4x more than other starships per slot), although the "low end" for minimum size C Class [b]Freighters has been bumped up from 5mil to 25mil[/b], so assuming you avoid using the initial free freighter, saving up for your first usable one might may take a little bit.
[*][b]Frigates also had their "base" price raised from 2 to 4mil (5 to 6mil for Pirate Frigates, and reduced 10 to 8mil for Organic Frigates, and 200mil to 100mil for unique frigates like the Normandy)[/b], although higher Class Frigates only cost a reasonable amount more than C Class. (This is because Higher Class Frigates are already undesirable, as they supposedly are more likely to have poor stat rolls)
[*]The base prices for Multi-Tools are mostly the same, but they follow the same pattern as starships with higher Classes costing up to 4x or 5x as much as C Class (8x for S Class Pistols)
[*]Thanks to an adapted portion of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/1626]gExo's Challenge Modpack﻿ by Exosolar & Gumsk[/url]﻿, your [b]exosuit starts with fewer Tech slots[/b], and the cost for increasing them eventually grows to tens of millions of units for each inventory page. This prevents maxing out inventory right away, and incentivizes finding & using Drop Pods.
[*]The prices for [b]expanding Multi-Tool / Starship inventories[/b] have also been rebalanced for smoother increases and being more competitive with simply buying a larger version (though still generally cheaper on a per-slot basis to buy a bigger ship/tool than expand it yourself)
[*]Cost to unlock additional [b]Pet Slots[/b] in the Companion Registry are now capped at [b]16k [/b]instead of 20k Nanites, and rises half as quickly as in Vanilla
[*][b]Exosuit Upgrade Charts are no longer sold in groups of dozens at a time[/b] in certain shops and are also more expensive (Now only found in batches of 1~4 or so), and Exocraft/Exomech [b]Scanners can no longer search for Drop Pods[/b].
[*]The various Sentinel Hardframe or Liquidator tech upgrades for the Minotaur now each [b]require a Hardframe Engine [/b]to install, so that the player must be strong enough to defeat Sentinel Mechs before gaining these techs or completing the "Trace of Metal" quest. In exchange, some of them no longer require Pugneum / Life Support Gel, to stay under the 3-ingredient UI display limit. The Liquidator Mech techs additionally require more expensive components compared to the Sentinel hardframe versions, as they don't require a quest to unlock.
[*][b]Salvaged Glass is no longer normally dropped by Drones, [/b]but instead by Sentinel Quads, Mechs, or Walkers, in increasing amounts (with a small chance to be found in Sentinel Pillars also).  Salvaged Glass is also half as likely as vanilla to yield an exosuit / Multi-Tool upgrade when opened. It should be harder to get powerful upgrades from sentinels than in vanilla, as these Sentinels are now more difficult than vanilla. (There is a rare [b]1% chance[/b] for Drones to also drop Salvaged Glass)
[*]The ability to access the secret "[b]discordant interface[/b]" terminals at Monoliths in Korvax systems and purchase [b]Atlantid Multi-Tools[/b] now unlocks during the "[b]A Leap in the Dark[/b]" main story mission after inspecting some Monoliths, instead of after completing the entire main story and starting Autophage missions. This spaces out the unlocking of Atlantid & Staff multi-tools further apart from each other, especially since the large Mining & yield bonuses of Atlantid Multi-Tools are more useful earlier in the game. Added notes to the in-game dialogue and mission tip during "A Leap in the Dark" when Atlantid multi-tools become available.
[*]Amount of [b]Atlantideum [/b]required to charge & activate Discordant Interfaces at Korvax Monoliths increased [b]~2x[/b]
[*]Similar to the above change, [b]p[/b][b]urple systems[/b] can now also be revealed & accessed earlier by taking a [b]new item[/b] (Dissonant Compass) unlocked from [b]Hyperion [/b]at the [b]Space Anomaly[/b] to a [b]Discordant Interface[/b], then purchasing the [b]Atlantid Drive[/b] plans from Hyperion for [b]12,000 nanites[/b] (this also makes purple systems accessible in [b]Abandoned Mode[/b]). Revealing purple systems and learning the plans for the Atlantid Drive can instead still be done for free the vanilla way by fully completing the [b]Artemis[/b], [b]Atlas[/b], and [b]Autophage [/b]questlines (although the Atlas questline takes much longer to complete in PTSd than vanilla).
[/list][/spoiler]
[b][size=3]Passive Farming/Mining Changes[/size][/b]
[spoiler][list]
[*]Frigate Expeditions only yield [b]0.8x [/b]of the units, [b]0.6x [/b]of the Products, and [b]0.2x [/b]of the Substances as vanilla (only [b]0.1x [/b]of Activated Metals). Additionally, they yield Platinum in place of Indium. 
[*]For certain [b]Expedition Interventions[/b] which give the player an option of paying units, the [b]optional cost[/b] is increased [b]2x[/b]. For certain Intervention [b]attempts [/b]which [b]fail [/b]and then penalize the player by costing units, the [b]cost [/b]is increased [b]4x[/b]. 
[*]Thanks to an adaptation of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/1369]Gumsk's Base Building - gBase﻿ by Gumsk[/url]﻿, mineral/Gas [b]Extractors fill 0.5x as fast [/b](at S Class), Extractors & Supply Depots can [b]only hold 0.5x as much[/b], and each base you build is [b]limited to 8 Mineral Extractors, 8 Gas Extractors, and 16 Supply Depots[/b]. Passive mining is not as easy a way to get rich or flush with resources now. ([b]Note[/b]: As a bonus side effect, Extractors round their extraction rate to the nearest multiple of 6.25 units/hour, so it ﻿requires a little less precision / finickiness to place Extractors for optimal yield compared to vanilla)
[*]Additionally, to prevent any Class hotspot from filling up all attached silos overnight, the difference between different Classes of mineral/gas hotspots has been greatly widened, with [b]C/B/A Class Mineral/Gas hotspots yield reduced to ~0.14x-0.29x[/b] (S Class unchanged). While 8 extractors over either an A & S Class hotspot can still fill a full set of 16 Silos in a day (and on A Class can even fill a half-set of 8 silos overnight, for bases splitting silos between 2 or more substances such as for gas & mineral), only S Class will mine fast enough to accumulate significant amounts during a typical play session. B Class needs just over 2 days to fill a full set of silos, or can get a half-set ~77% full after a day. C Class needs ~3 days to fill a full set of silos, or can get a half-set ~55% full after a day. 
[*]Since PTSd already restricts Mineral & Gas extraction by limiting how many Extractors & Supply Depots you can have per base, Diminishing Returns for mineral/gas extractors has been disabled, so that hotspot Class is still actually meaningful. (Technically I moved the threshold to activate it 5x higher, but you can't reach that high in PTSd anyways)
[*][b]Fixed [/b]what is presumably a vanilla typo as of the [b]NMS Relics[/b] update that scrambled the strengths of Power/Mineral/Gas hotspots
[/list][list]
[*]A number of materials found in mineral deposits are now actually worth more than in vanilla, due to recent vanilla updates over-correcting their prices down from earlier too-high prices:
[*] ﻿ ﻿All Stellar Metals (Copper, Cadmium, etc.), Activated Stellar Metals, and Chromatic Metal have [b]had their value increased 1.15x~1.4x[/b], so that they maintain a pattern of the value of each metal raw is 95% of refining it into Chromatic Metal. 
[*] ﻿ ﻿Cobalt & Ionised Cobalt have [b]had their value increased ~1.7x[/b]. 
[*] ﻿ ﻿Salt & Chlorine have [b]had their value increased ~1.6x[/b]. 
[*] ﻿ ﻿Most mineral deposit mines are still much less appealing for profit than pre-4.0 vanilla, and Silver & Gold deposits remain an appealing option for making money.
[/list][list]
[*]In contrast, the carbon-fueled early-game harvesters (Autonomous Mining Unit, Gas Harvester, Oxygen Harvester) now complete a full cycle [b]6x / 6x / 1.2x faster[/b]. ﻿Since they are buggy in vanilla and often lose their contents when reloading or leaving the system, now it should be easier to have them complete at least a partial cycle while you are still in the area in one play session, either at your base or landing on a planet. (I find deleting & rebuilding them each time I refuel them also prevents issues). Added to their descriptions to note their duration time in PTSd and tips for avoiding the vanilla glitch which sometimes clears their inventory.
[*]The [b]Antimatter Reactor[/b] completes its cycle [b]1.2x faster[/b], but only [b]yields 0.4x[/b] as much Antimatter, and now costs 10 each of Storm Crystals, Antimatter, and Dark Matter (4th Atlas Seed) to build.
[/list][list]
[*][b]Biofuel Reactors[/b] cost ~[b]3.5x[/b] as much [b]Oxygen [/b]and [b]4x Metal Plates[/b] to build, and only last [b]half as long[/b] when full ([b]25 hours[/b] instead of 50) while still costing the same amount to refill, thus are half as efficient
[/list][list]
[*][b]Solar Panels[/b] now cost [b]4 Metal Plates, 60 Gold, & 4 Glass [/b]to construct, instead of 1 Metal Plate, 30 Gold, & 50 Chromatic Metal.
[/list][list]
[*][b]Batteries[/b] now cost ~[b]1.3x Magnetised Ferrite [/b]and [b]30 Ionised Cobalt [/b]to construct.
[/list][list]
[*][b]Electromagnetic Generators[/b] now cost [b]3x the materials[/b] to construct. However they still end up roughly [b]~3x-6x[/b] (depending on hotspot Class) as [b]cost-effective[/b] to build in terms of resources needed per kP produced when compared to the alternatives. (Also, B Class power hotspot strength slightly reduced to match the pattern of the other hotspot classes)
[*]Stellar Extractors now [b]cost 2x[/b] the Silver & Gold, and also [b]cost 6 Gravitino Balls[/b].
[*]﻿Automated Trap now requires Emeril, Living Pearls, and larger amounts of Metal Plating to build
[*][b]Settlements provide substantially more Products / Substances[/b] as vanilla, and offer a [b]wider variety[/b] of both generic & race-specific items to choose to produce. Production rates, storage caps, and individual items have all been adjusted.
[*] ﻿ ﻿By default most settlements can store up to [b]3 days[/b] worth of production before collecting
[*] ﻿ ﻿[b]NOTE[/b]: A [b]Vanilla bug[/b] causes settlement production rates to become slightly [b]slower [/b]as the settlement develops instead of becoming faster, so settlements with [b]low [/b]population/happiness/productivity will actually produce items [b]faster[/b]
[*] ﻿[b]Gek [/b]produce all items [b]1.2x faster[/b], but can only store [b]0.6x[/b] as many items (1.5 days worth). [b]Vy'Keen[/b] produce all items [b]0.8x as fast[/b], but can store [b]1.6x[/b] as many items (6 days worth). [b]Korvax/Autophage[/b] use the [b]base [/b]production rate & storage cap
[*] ﻿On top of these rate/cap adjustments, each race specializes in a certain settlement building and the category of items it produces, producing those items [b]1.2x[/b] faster with a [b]1.2x[/b] larger storage cap. Gek specialize in Commercial buildings (Trade Goods), Vy'Keen specialize in Agricultural buildings (crops), Korvax specialize in Starports (fuels), and Autophage specialize in Industrial buildings (crafting ingredients).
[*] ﻿ ﻿(The above settlement strengths/weaknesses are now listed in the Settlement Mission Log description and Settlement Guide in-game)
[*] ﻿ ﻿Each race should now have a method of [b]generating nanites[/b] (Refining Inverted Mirrors / Radiant Shards for Autophage, direct Nanites for Korvax, selling upgrade modules from Salvaged Glass for Vy'keen, donating cakes/pies to Cronus for Gek)
[*] ﻿ ﻿Greatly increased the production rate of [b]Trade Goods[/b], so now having 4 top-tier settlements can result in ~4.8 million units worth of Trade Goods per day. Gek settlements can reach a further ~1.5x as many units per day on top of this, compared to other settlements. [b]New settlements[/b] can now produce at least some Trade goods even without any Commerical buildings. Producing [b]Crafting Ingredients[/b] such as Enriched Carbon or Semiconductors will yield [b]less [/b]profits if sold directly, but are [b]more [/b]profitable if "upgraded" via crafting before selling.
[*] ﻿ ﻿Settlements now complete a production cycle of most items [b]every 2.4 hours[/b] instead of 20 hours. This means whenever making a Settlement decision that adds any Debt (which causes the production cycle to reset to 0 once the debt is repaid), you will usually lose at most ~2.4 hours' worth of production instead of 20 hours' worth of production. I.E. Visiting your settlement and making decisions more than once a day no longer prevents your settlement from ever producing items; you should most likely be able to collect at least some items every day as long as Productivity > Maintenance costs, and it's more feasible to delay making a Debt-increasing settlement decision until the current production cycle finishes first.
[*][b] ﻿ ﻿Settlement [/b]"[b]Expeditions[/b]" now have only a [b]15% chance[/b] to fail instead of a 30% chance, and the chance is listed in the expedition description.
[*][b]Wild [/b]versions of farmed plants have had their [b]yield increased to ~1.8x[/b] (still lower yield than player planted), to make "wild foraging" more competitive with starting your own farm.
[*] ﻿ ﻿[b]Settlement Towers[/b] have their abilities (collect Navigation Data, Scan for nearby buildings, etc.) recharge in [b]20 hours[/b] instead of 24 hours.
[*][b]Standing Planters[/b] cost [b]5x[/b] as much [b]Salvaged Data[/b] to unlock, yield [b]0.5x as much carbon[/b], and cannot be built on Freighters (where they would receive free power). Also, the walls of leafy freighter rooms yield [b]0.2x as much carbon[/b].
[*]Crafted Trade goods made from farm plants have [b]had their value changed between 1x to 0.15x[/b] at the highest tier, and the jump in value between each tier has been reduced. Time spent gathering crops, teleporting between bases, sorting inventory, and crafting (ignoring growth time) is still significantly more profitable in units per minute than most "active" activities, but only somewhere in the ballpark of ~5x more profitable instead of 100x. This also makes it less of a "no-brainer" decision on whether to save up the intermediate products to craft later vs. selling some for decent cash now.
[*]Various costs & attributes for the [b]various methods of growing crops[/b] have been further adjusted to give most of them a beneficial niche when considering costs on a "per-plant" basis (their descriptions now note their relative strengths):
[*]﻿ ﻿○  [b]Hydroponics Tray[/b] requires [b]less than half[/b] the normal ingredients, so it is now the [b]most cost-effective[/b]  option in terms of construction cost per-plant, able to grow 50% more than the Large Trays with the same amount of substances. However its [b]power draw[/b] was increased [b]+20%[/b]
[*] ﻿○ [b]Large Hydroponics Tray[/b] requires slightly [b]more[/b] ingredients to build (1.5x Metal Plates), and thus on a per-plant basis [b]costs 50% more[/b] to construct than regular Trays. However its [b]power draw[/b] has been reduced [b]-20%[/b], and is now the [b]most power-efficient[/b] of all planetary options on a per-plant basis. Thus you can grow 50% more plants than the regular Trays with the same amount of power.
[*] ○ [b]Biodome [/b]needs [b]many more[/b] ingredients to construct: ~20x more Magnetised Ferrite and now also 320 Oxygen (However as it has [b]16 plots[/b], on a per-plant basis the cost is actually in between regular & Large Trays). Its [b]power draw[/b] is [b]3x[/b] vanilla, so on a per-plant basis is nearly double the regular Tray or triple the Large Tray, but are the [b]most time-efficient[/b] of all options with the powerful ability to [b]harvest 16 plants at once[/b].
[*] ○ [b]Cultivation Chamber[/b] & [b]Double Cultivation Chamber[/b] use Faecium instead of Oxygen and had their required ingredients substantially increased (1.4x ~ 4x) so that the Double Cultivation Chamber costs 50% more than the regular one on a per-plant basis. They are by far the[b] highest cost[/b] to construct on a per-plant basis, but [b]get all their power for free[/b], can [b]harvest 2 or 4 plants at once[/b], and are [b]conveniently located[/b] on your Freighter.
[*]The "Commodity" crops of Gravitino Host, Venom Urchin, Albumen Pearl, NipNip Buds now have niches to make them more useful. All except Nipnip Buds [b]also yield a small amount of Nanites[/b] ([b]8, 12, or 1)[/b] in addition to their normal crop when harvested. Their growth times have also been changed (and the construction UI adjusted to reflect this, as well as their descriptions giving an overview of their strengths) so that their strengths are: ﻿
[*] [b]Gravitino Host[/b] - 4hr growth time, lowest units/hour & units/harvest, but [b]highest Nanites/hour[/b]. ﻿﻿Recipe now requires a Gravitino Ball and some Cadmium instead of Chromatic Metal & Magnetised Ferrite.
[*][b] ﻿Venom Urchin[/b] - 16hr growth time (so only needs tending once a day), low Nanites/hr & units/hour, but [b]highest[/b] [b]units/harvest[/b], so ideal if you only plan to harvest once per day. (Restored ability to view remaining growth time for Venom Urchins that was removed in vanilla) ﻿
[*] [b]Albumen Pearl Orb[/b] - 1hr growth time, low nanites/hr & units/harvest, but [b]highest units/hr[/b]. However as it requires hourly harvesting to reach the full potential, the units/manhour is actually fairly low (IE you will spend more in-game time traveling to your farm and harvesting compared to other crops)
[*] [b]NipNip Buds[/b] - 4.333hr growth time, no nanites, but high units/hr & units/harvest with a [b]good balance between them[/b]. While Venom Sac will have ~+50% higher units/harvest, and Albumen Pearl ~+50% higher units/hour, for many playstyles NipNip Buds will likely hit the sweet spot of "best" combination of overall profitbaility. ﻿Recipe now requires 3 NipNip Buds and some Platinum, so it will be slower to expand your # of farm plots compared to other crops.
[*] These are balanced in order of difficulty of gathering the resources needed to construct the plant, generally balanced to be about [b]~2/3 as profitable as growing ingredients[/b] for the "corresponding" tier of craftable farm products in exchange for skipping all the hassle of actually crafting things (and often getting some nanites on the side). E.G. Gravitino Host yielding profits about 2/3 as high as growing ingredients for Acid, Venom Urchin is ~2/3 as high as Circuit Boards, and NipNip Buds being ~2/3 as high as Fusion Ignitors, etc., although sometimes the balance between units/hour and units/harvest are adjusted towards one or the other. 
[/list][/spoiler]
[b][size=3]Activity Reward Changes[/size][/b]
[spoiler]
[list]
[*]The base scan value for Fauna & Minerals has been reduced to [b]0.75x [/b]vanilla to balance out the added inherent Scan bonus of all Multi-Tools with PTSd (Flora value unchanged to compensate for hazardous & oxygen/sodium/deuterium plants no longer being scannable). Thus an S Class Pistol or Experimental Multi-Tool will give an [b]effective scan value of 1.05x or ~1.69x [/b]vanilla, before any upgrades. 
[*]The [b]scanning speed[/b] for scanning new fauna/flora/minerals has been [b]increased ~1.8x[/b] to make exploring new planets a bit faster.
[*]The Nanite reward for recording [b]new discoveries[/b] of star systems, planets, flora, and minerals have been [b]increased by 5x~7x[/b] (fauna discoveries only increased [b]~1.5x[/b] as they already have a huge nanite reward available for discovering all fauna on a planet). Also, [b]activating waypoints[/b] (the save beacons which yield Navigation Data) gives 3a location/region on a planet at the randomly found save/navigation beacons gives [b]3x [/b]nanites, and [b]recording a new location[/b] discovery from a waypoint gives [b]20x [/b]nanites. Altogether this should make general exploring more rewarding and viable as an activity, nanites-wise.
[*]The [b]huge nanite bonus[/b] for discovering [b]all fauna on a planet[/b] is [b]unchanged[/b], but creatures are much more likely to either be found [b]only in the North / South[/b] of a planet, or be active [b]mostly/only[/b] at [b]night/during the day[/b] (in particular [b]predators [/b]& [b]glowing creatures[/b] are more likely to be active at night, [b]plant-creatures[/b] are more likely to be active during the day). Most planets should now have 1~2 creatures on average which are only found in the North/South hemisphere, and "Always Active" creatures will tend to be in the minority. This both makes the creatures you see vary more with your location & time of day, but also makes getting the huge nanite bonus for fauna require more effort than simply landing and scanning for ~30 seconds. The recommended mod [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/3328?tab=description]gCreatures Underground Creature Fix (3x version)[/url]﻿ will help offset this added difficulty by making underground creatures much easier to find.
[*] ﻿ ﻿Neither of the above changes to creature location / time of day activity should affect creature generation / sync with vanilla discovery data, etc. but just in case, both sets of changes can be toggled off at the top of "[b]PTSd Creature Loot Changes.lua[/b]". Alternatively, deleting all folders & files besides "[i]CREATUREPETBEHAVIOURTABLE.MBIN[/i]" in [b]MODS\PTSd Incoming Damage and Predators\METADATA\SIMULATION\ECOSYSTEM[/b] will disable these changes.
[*]A variety of "valuable" items found in the wild have [b]had their value increased[/b] in order to reward exploring more, or incentivize visiting particular areas (e.g. Underwater). Sac Venom, Albumen Pearls, Vortex Cubes, Gek Relics, Vy'Keen Effigies, Korvax Casings, Inverted Mirrors, and Hypnotic Eyes have all [b]had their value per harvest increased by 2x~4x[/b] (Albumen Pearls, Sac Venom, and Gravitino Balls are a special case where in the wild they yield 2x items at 0.5x value each, to maintain balance for their farmed versions). Underwater items such as Crystal Sulphide and Living Pearls have even larger (effective) [b]boosts of 5x or 9x[/b] to incentivize underwater exploration even more. The "rare" relics of Korvax Cubes, Vy'Keen Daggers, and Geknip are all [b]boosted by 10x[/b], and the unique drops from advanced sentinels (Quad Servo, Hardframe Engine, Crystallised Heart, and Walker Brain) are [b]boosted between 4x~8x[/b]. [b]Hex Cores[/b] increased by [b]~1000x[/b] (were previously just 16 units)
[/list][list]
[*]Gravitino Balls have their value [b]reduced to ~0.4x[/b] to [b]16161 [/b]units, but in the wild have a [b]33% chance to yield 16 nanites [i]in addition[/i][/b] to a Gravitino Ball.
[*]Vortex Cubes are still worth less than Albumen Pearls, but now have a [b]66[/b][b]% chance to yield 4 nanites [i]in addition[/i][/b] to a Vortex Cube.
[/list][list]
[*]Storm Crystals have had their [b]value reduced to 0.6x[/b], but now have a [b]50% chance to yield 8 nanites [i]in addition[/i][/b] to a Storm Crystal
[*]Certain items (Albumen Pearl, Crystal Sulphide, Vortex Cube) have had their default [b]stack size increased to 10, 15, or 20 per slot[/b], so they can achieve a "per slot" profit to justify using the inventory space to gather them.
[*]﻿[b]Increased the sale value[/b] of all "[b]geode[/b]" style items (Geode<Ferrite>, Geode<Cobalt>, Gold Nugget, Glowing Mineral) by [b]~4x-15x[/b] so that they each sell for at least [b]double[/b] the average value of opening them and selling their contents (some "geodes" that are harder to get or contain less valuable items have their value increased even more). In exchange, their default stacksize is lower from 25 to 15. Now there is a choice of whether you want to break them down for their substances to use for fuel / crafting more valuable items to sell, or to sell them as-is for decent money.
[*]To aid in gathering materials for underwater construction, each gem on an underwater [b]Thermal Vents yields 2x [/b]Crystal Sulphide, and each "pod" on an [b]Alluring Specimens yields 1x [/b]Hadal Core, [b]2x [/b]Crystal Sulphide, and [b]1x[/b] Living Pearl. (As a side effect of another PTSd change, Alluring Specimens no longer get destroyed on "bad reaction")
[*]To further encourage going underwater to gather resources, harvesting alluring Specimens are slightly less likely to trigger a "bad reaction" ([b]45% chance[/b] from 50% chance), and mining underwater resources is [b]half as likely[/b] to spawn jellyfish ([b]15% chance[/b] from 30% chance)
[*][b]Sea Glass[/b] can now only be found at depths of [b]800u [/b]or below (~160u past the point where "[b]Hyperpressure[/b]" is in effect), instead of at 220u or below to make it less accessible
[*][b]Sea Glass[/b] value increased [b]1.2x[/b], now replaces Gold Nuggets as a daily option to trade to [b]Iteration Ares[/b] in the Anomaly for ~240 nanites each, can be refined with Microprocessors into Salvaged Data like most nanite-bearing items, and also has [b]3 new glass-related refining recipes[/b], hinted at in its new description.
[*]Increased the richness of [b]deep sea mineral deposits[/b] by a further [b]2x[/b] to better compete with late-game mineral extractors
[*]The new interactable objects in [b]Space Stations[/b] ([b]Data Silos, Storage Containers[/b], etc.) are now roughly [b]~5x[/b] more likely to yield [b]Navigation Data,[/b] can now yield [b]Pure Ferrite[/b], yield [b]~0.1x[/b] as much Ferrite Dust/Pure Ferrite/Magnetised Ferrite with lower chances for higher-tier Ferrite. Units yields have already been increased ~100x as PTSd automatically increases small unit rewards, and the rewards of [b]10-15 Units[/b] from some objects have been changed to [b]Nanites [/b]as that is presumably what was intended.
[*][b]Killing planetary creatures[/b] now only yields [b]~0.25x[/b] as much "[b]meat[/b]" and [b]Mordite[/b], and non-predatory creatures have [b]~1.5x[/b] as much [b]health[/b] ("Walking Buildings" additionally have damage resistance, taking only 0.15x damage from the player). Gathering enormous quantities of meat products or Mordite should be a little more difficult, and possibly make the alternative sources/recipes for these items more appealing.
[*]"[b]Rock Creatures[/b]" / "[b]Living Rocks[/b]" now drop multiple [b]Glowing Minerals[/b] instead of Meaty Chunks when killed, an extra incentive for doing mining by hand with a laser, and "Robot Antelope" drop ﻿1~2 Industrial-Grade Batteries instead of 1~2 nanites when killed.
[*]The consumable plant item found in [b]Subterranean Organic Structures[/b] has had some of the possible "junk" rewards such as "Residual Goop" or "Viscous Fluids" replaced with more useful items such as Marrow Bulbs, Sweetroots, or Pulpy Roots. Also increased the amount rewarded for some other items such as Runaway Mould, Carbon, etc. to make these consumables overall more worthwhile & desirable.
[*]Replaced the [b]Cadmium/Emeril/Indium[/b] rewards from dismantling broken tech consumables found in [b]Buried Caches[/b] with their [b]Activated [/b]versions to prevent "sequence breaking" before getting the appropriate hyperdrive techs.
[*][b]Resource Depots[/b] have better chances to yield the more valuable products, and yield ~2x more Substances for Substance rewards.
[*][b]Ancient Bones [/b]and [b]Salvageable Scrap[/b] sites have modestly increased profitability, but are adjusted so that Ancient Bones provides [b]much more consistent rewards[/b] if you are just gathering a few at a time for a guaranteed profit, while [b]Scrap[/b] normally yield fewer units except for [b]rare [/b]finds which [b]average out to higher profits than Bones[/b]. This only works when you take the time (and have enough storage) to harvest many Scrap nodes until you happen across some rare ones to make it worthwhile (notably, the Protective Casings surround Scrap nodes now also have a chance to drop additional Scrap items). Also, this is assuming you are taking the time to wait for Sentinels to stop investigating you while mining the Scrap. If you have the speed & survivability to anger the Sentinels and continue harvesting, then Scrap pulls further ahead in units per minute. If you are able to quickly dispatch Golems from Vigilant Eyes however, the profits/minute from Ancient Bones sites can go up as well. (However, Scrap is now [b]0.5x[/b] as likely to drop [b]Sentinel Boundary Maps[/b] as vanilla, and destroying the components surrounding Salvageable Scrap cores yields Rusted Metal instead of Ferrite Dust and yields ~0.25x as much)
[*] ﻿Different types of Bones from Ancient Bones sites now have slightly different values, making some of them worthwhile to cook while others will lose value if cooked. Also, currently packaged Exhibits are discouraged from being sold in their descriptions as I've yet to find a way to lwoer their value.
[*]With the addition of [b]Corvette modules[/b] to the loot table for many loot sources, PTSd greatly lowers their droprate from Salvageable Scrap, but slightly increases the amount dropped from the optional reward at the end of Derelict Freighters, and doubles their droprate from "derelict corvettes" found in space.
[*]Many rare "[b]three star[/b]" POIs such as Curious Deposits, Mutant Plants, Organic Rocks, etc. have had their substance yield [b]reduced to ~0.3x-0.75x.[/b] Additional, Metal "Fingers" now have a ratio of 2:1 of Gold : Uranium fingers instead of 1:1. However Radon Mutant Plants are unchanged, and Chlorine Organic Rocks are increased 3x
[*]Rewards of small amount of units (between 75,000 ~ 500) [b]have been increased by 4x ~125x[/b] (larger increases for smaller amounts of units). This includes things such as "Checking Stock transfer," gifts from NPC dialogue, terminals, containers, quest rewards, etc.
[*]Adjusted the yields and chances for different [b]Asteroid [/b]resources, such as larger amounts of Silver & Gold directly, fewer Gold Nuggets, etc. Overall when opening all Hyperclusters & Nuggets the result is that on average you should get about [b]0.8x[/b] as much Tritium, [b]~1.5x[/b] as much Silver, [b]~1.3x[/b] as much Platinum, and roughly the [b]same [/b]Gold. Thus you should now actually get more Silver than Gold from asteroids.
[*]Chances for a system to be filled with rare [b]Platinum asteroids[/b] decreased [b]~0.4x[/b] in Red systems, increased [b]2x [/b]& [b]1.5x[/b] in Green & Blue systems so that the chance always [b]increases [/b]with [b]higher-tier[/b] system colour
[*]Rewards for defeating "wandering" pirate bounties that randomly appear in space have been[b] increased by 3x ~ 8x[/b], especially for the more difficult variants ([b]up to 4mil units[/b]). This is partially offset by the increased difficulty of enemy ships with PTSd, and the vanilla bug where defeating "wandering" pirate bounties often yields no reward.
[*]The units reward for defeating a planetary pirate raid is increased by [b]1.5x[/b], and additionally awards roughly [b]~200 nanites[/b].
[*]Rewards for[b] defeating spaceships [/b]have been slightly improved; Pirates are [b]0.25x [/b]as likely to drop race relics, drop more nanites, and drop better loot for more difficult Pirates, Sentinel Interceptors are ~[b]0.8x[/b] as likely to drop Pugneum and now can drop Explosive Drones, Trader & Trader Escort ships can now drop Mind Control Devices, Trader Escorts drops skew towards upgrade modules while Traders skew towards sellable items, Freighter Cargo Pods drop 5x the amount of substances and can now drop Fuel Oxidizers and are [b]3x [/b]~ [b]4x [/b]as likely to drop Salvaged Frigate Modules (less likely for "smuggler" freighters). Destroying freighters now has a chance to drop Salvaged Frigate Modules, however they only award C Class Procedural Freighter Upgrade Modules instead of S Class. The nanites drops from Trader ships & Freighter cargo pods have been increased by [b]2x [/b]as well. Cargo Pods no longer display their contents in advance, and "Smuggler" freighters in Outlaw systems have reduced Cargo Pod rewards, as they have less defenses.
[*]However, while the overall quality of loot from defeating Pirate starships is improved, the ratio of ([b]Tech[/b])/([b]Arms[/b]) [b]Suspicious Packets[/b] to ([b]Goods[/b]) Packets has been [b]reduced [/b]from 2:1 to roughly ~[b]1:2[/b], moreso for weaker types of Pirates. This is to make it harder to quickly gain lots of powerful X-Class upgrades from defeating small gangs of weak pirates.
[*]Rebalanced the possible items found in all kinds of [b]Suspicious Packets[/b]
[*] ﻿ ﻿([b]Tech[/b]) Packets now can also have [b]Pulse Engine[/b] & [b]Launcher [/b]X-Class upgrades, and both (Tech) and (Arms) Packets can have various upgrades for [b]Exocraft [/b]/ [b]Minotaur [/b]/ [b]Nautilon[/b]. Since those upgrades don't come in X-Class, they will randomly be C/B/A/S Class, with lower chances for higher Classes.
[*] ﻿ ﻿([b]Goods[/b]) packets have the chances to award Repair Kits or Walker Brains reduced [b]0.5x[/b], various Trade Goods reduced [b]~0.15x[/b], and the possible amounts for many items such as Trade Goods, Geodes, Larval Cores, Gravitino Balls, etc. increased[b] 2~4x[/b]
[*]The unsalvageable "[b]mini-shipwrecks[/b]" added in NMS 5.0 are now roughly [b]half [/b]as likely to yield Suspicious Packets (Tech) instead of Suspicious Packets (Goods) or Anomaly Detectors
[*]The rewards for all Mission Radar (Corvette), space/Outlaw station or Nexus [b]Missions have been improved to roughly double the unit / nanite reward[/b] at each difficulty tier. Additionally, the rewards scale better with mission difficulty, eventually reaching less low-quality item rewards offered, larger quantity of items in the reward, [b]higher chances for higher quality items[/b] such as Storage Augmentation, and [b]chances for Freighter Bulkheads / Emergency Signal Scanners[/b] to be offered. The rewards for "hunting Pirates" missions in particular have been improved.
[*][b]Outlaw Station Mission[/b] rewards are [b]0.5x[/b] as likely to offer [b]Sentinel Boundary Maps[/b]
[*][b]Hardframe Engines[/b] have been added as rewards in place of or alongside Walker Brains for some [b]Space Station Missions[/b] / [b]Guild Gifts[/b] that normally only award Walker Brains. Useful as a slower / less predictable method of getting components for installing / repairing the Sentinel Hardframe upgrades for the Minotaur in PTSd.
[*][b]Inventory-type Memory Fragment[/b] (mostly from certain [b]Traveler [/b]dialogue rewards) now have a small chance to award a [b]Freighter Bulkhead[/b] instead of only Exosuit/Starship/Multi-Tool inventory slots
[*]Giving a Traveler 20 nanites now awards ~40 Di-Hydrogen & Tritium instead of units.
[*]﻿Containers / Datapads on [b]Derelict Freighters[/b] award [b]~4x as many nanites[/b]. This incentivizes exploring them thoroughly rather than rushing to the end, since more rooms & containers means more nanites. This should make Derelict Freighters one of the very best methods in terms of nanites/minute if also selling/refining other loot into nanites (at the cost of increasingly expensive Emergency Signal Scanners if trying to do them multiple times per day)
[*]Increased [b]nanite reward[/b] option at the end of a [b]Derelict Freighter by 3x[/b] to make it more competitive with the other choices. Added note to the dialogue choices to display the approximate amount of nanites to be awarded. (Added similar note to nanite reward option dialogue at Manufacturing Facilities)
[*]The [b]Class [/b]of [b]Freighter upgrade modules[/b] received as a reward option at the end of Derelict Freighters is now [b]truly randomized[/b] each run instead of being static based on the star system/region you're in (dialogue window now clarifies that the Tech will be truly random). However they are given generous chances ([b]10% C, 40% B, 30% A, & 20% S Class[/b]), and this can be toggled back to vanilla spawn rules with UsePTSdFreiUpgradeClassChances in "PTSd Rewards Remixer.lua"
[*]Turning over the [b]Crew Manifest[/b] / [b]Captain's Log[/b] from a Derelict Freighter to a [b]Scrap Dealer[/b] now awards the [b]same [/b]amount of Tainted Metal regardless of the ﻿in-game "Natural Resources" difficulty setting, and turning them into [b]Guild Representatives[/b] now awards even [b]more faction standing[/b], as well as either [b]600k or 900k units[/b] (Mission log & UI popup updated to note this). (These can also be turned in at Explorer Guild Envoys for some standing as well)
[*]As a solution for the [b]vanilla bug[/b] where sometimes the mission required to be able to trade in Crew Manifests / Captain's Logs disappears/fails to spawn, you can now [b]activate any Crew Manifest / Captain's Log[/b] from your inventory (once outside the Derelict Freighter) to [b]reactivate [/b]the "trade in Derelict items at Scrap Dealers or Guild Reps" mission. (Item description now indicates how to do so)
[*]As a backup just in case you're still unable to trade in Derelict Freighter Crew Manifests / Captain's Logs for some other reason (perhaps using gLonely with fewer NPCs available), they can now at least be [b]sold as items for ~0.85x the units[/b] you would get for trading them to Guild Reps in PTSd.
[*]Reward for scavenging [b]Crashed Freighters have been improved[/b]: increased chances for items such as Salvaged Frigate Modules or Multi-Tool Expansion slots, and a decent [b]chance for Freighter Bulkheads[/b].
[*][b]Opening containers[/b] at Crashed Freighters once again has a cost: now requires [b]10 Chromatic Metal[/b] to open each container
[*]Rewards for rescuing Freighters from pirate starships: now yields Tritium instead of Gold, increased nanite reward by [b]1.5x[/b], and additionally awards roughly ~[b]700k units, [/b]and[b] a Salvaged Frigate Module[/b].
[*]Rewards for rescuing Freighters from [b]Pirate Dreadnoughts[/b] now always give at least [b]several hundred Nanites[/b] and either [b]Salvaged Frigate Modules[/b] or[b] Cargo Bulkheads,[/b] with even greater unit/nanite/item rewards for defeating the Pirate Dreadnought. Also, destroying parts of the Dreadnought now can yield loot: Shield Generators now have a chance to drop Starshield Batteries, Warp Drives & Exposed Fuel Rods have a chance to drop Frigate Fuel (50t), Anti-Ship/Freighter Turrets/Cannons drop ~16/~100 Nanites, and Pirate Frigates drop the same loot as "Easy" PTSd Pirate starships.
[*]Large Artifact Chests in Ruins now always drop a [b]guaranteed Common rarity Tool in addition[/b] to the normal random artifact. This Tool should always be accepted at most Colossal Archive Artifact Vaults. This should make Ruins more worth the time investment, especially with the following change.
[*][b]Colossal Archive Artifact Vaults now always yield guaranteed Rare artifacts[/b] in return. Archives don't always accept artifacts, which take up a lot of inventory space if saving them to deposit, so the reward should be large enough to justify the time & effort.
[*]Units option to "[b]Bargain for Relic[/b]" with space traders [b]cost [/b]reduced from [b]850k[/b] to [b]400k [/b]units in most cases (will instead be equal to 1% of the total value of your cargo, if that is higher). This should now make paying units for the relic [b]turn a profit on average[/b] instead of overwhelmingly losing money (now should be 40% chance to lose 200-300k, 40% chance to make 0-300k, and 20% chance to make 400k - 1.6 million units), although in PTSd you can [b]always [/b]turn a profit if you are able to trade the relic in at a Colossal Archive. 
[*]Learning words from Knowledge Stones or Encyclopedias (not NPCs) [b]teaches 2 words at a time[/b], to encourage exploration. Ancient Plaques & Monoliths now [b]teach ~5 words at a time[/b] when choosing to learn words from them, to make it a worthwhile option.
[*]﻿Added guaranteed substantial [b]Units [/b]& [b]Nanites [/b]rewards to the [b]Exocraft Technician NPC's[/b] repeatable daily mission, in addition to the usual random upgrade module/product reward, to make it more worthwhile. Also, upgrade modules will always be at least B Class, with [b]double [/b]the chance for A or S Class, and can award [b]Minotaur [/b]upgrades as well as standard Exocraft upgrades.
[*]Choosing to "Extract Nanites" at a Manufacturing Facility instead of learning a recipe or making a Multi-Tool Expansion Slot [b]now yields ~4x more Nanites[/b], to make it more comparable to the other options.
[*]The "[b]Gassy Pods[/b]" you can collect from the common exploding gas plant hazardous flora now give [b]0.2x[/b] as much [b]Oxygen[/b]. Now collecting all 3 Gassy Pods before destroying the plant gives an additional ~+150% added Oxygen vs. ignoring the pods instead of vanilla's ~+500% added Oxygen.
[*][b]Green damaged crates[/b] now give [b]~0.67x[/b] as much [b]Rusted Metal[/b]
[*]When interacting with [b]damaged sentinel machinery[/b] on Corrupt Planets, you will now [b]only receive a single item[/b]. This is to prevent you from otherwise getting full stacks of Salvaged Glass, Inverted Mirrors, Quad Servos, or Walker Brains as in vanilla.
[*][b]Harmonic Scrap[/b] wheelbarrows in Abandoned Camps have [b]increased chances[/b] of better rewards.
[*][b]Echo Locators[/b] droprate from Dissonance Resonators reduced to ~[b]0.6x [/b]vanilla chance, but droprate from the large [b]Arachnid Sentinels[/b] increased to [b]2.7x[/b] vanilla chance, to incentivize fighting them.
[*][b]Vile Queens[/b] now always drop ~250 Runaway Mould, with a 50% chance to also drop a procedural loot item of Uncommon rarity/value. The chance to drop the new bug helmets is now 50%~12.5% depending on how many you've already found, instead of a flat 25%. However, all Vile Queens on the same planet will drop the same loot, so obtaining all the helmets will require visiting multiple planets with Vile Queens.
[*]Similarly, [b]Deepsea Guardians[/b] now also drop [b]~4 Flesh Rope[/b] and [b]~10 Jellymeat[/b] on defeat to give them some value.
[*][b]﻿[/b][b]Iteration Ares[/b]' daily offer to trade certain items for nanites at the Anomaly should be much more appealing now: Increased nanite reward [b]3x~15x[/b] per item, trades items in batches of [b]3~10 items at a time[/b], now accepts [b]Glowing Minerals[/b], [b]Pirate Transponders, [/b]&[b] Sea Glass[/b] in place of Gravitino Balls, Salvaged Data, & Gold Nuggets (so that all accepted items are the result of exploring and cannot be passively farmed, and to give more use to Sea Glass), and thanks to an adaptation of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/2290]Reikokuu & Babscoole's "Keep Talking Chef"[/url]﻿, you can now [b]repeatedly [/b]trade batches of items with Ares without exiting & restarting their dialogue interaction each time. The description of all items which can be an option for a daily Ares trade now mention this, to make it easier to keep track of which items are worth saving.
[*][b]Gas Giants[/b] now spawn a [b]larger variety of vacant buildings[/b] such as Plaques, Monoliths, Ruins, etc., and have a higher density of crashed starships/freighters and Damaged Machinery than regular planets (due to vessels getting pulled in by the strong gravity) to make them more rewarding to explore.
[*][b]Vigilant Stone[/b] value increased [b]~1.6x[/b], but they are no longer received from disturbing Vigilant Eyes directly, instead [b]Mech/Floating Golems[/b] have a chance to [b]drop them on defeat[/b]. Vigilant Eyes now award some Polished Stone instead.
[*]﻿[b]Reduced [/b]the chances of finding very valuable items in the new loot boxes on [b]Abandoned Stations[/b] such as upgrade modules, Emergency Signal Scanners, inventory expansion items, etc. In exchange, these boxes can now contain a wider variety of generally useful items such as Repair Kits, Larval Cores, Navigation Data, etc. Also, these boxes have higher chances for some of the better rewards when opened in [b]Abandoned Mode[/b]. Additionally, the boxes in Abandoned Stations might "remember" that you've already opened them for longer, making it harder to repeatedly loot them instead of visiting new systems (difficult to test to confirm this).
[*]In [b]Abandoned Mode[/b], [b]Buried Caches[/b] & [b]Crashed Freighter[/b] Containers are both less likely to contain inventory expansion items, and Crashed Freighter Containers are now more likely to contain the more valuable items such as Emergency Signal Scanners, higher Class upgrade modules, inventory expansion items, etc. compared to Buried Caches. Exosuit Expansion Units found in Abandoned stations and Buried Caches in Abandoned Mode (but not Crashed Freighter Containers) now replaced with Exosuit Upgrade Charts
[*]﻿[b]Memory Stones[/b] on ruined worlds now each require [b]64 Polished Stone[/b] to access, ﻿but now after learning all Ruins blueprints instead of awarding ~150 nanites, there is a 50/50 chance to either award [b]~350 nanites[/b] or a random procedural [b]Loot treasure[/b] worth [b]~400,000 units[/b] on average. This puts them roughly in the ballpark of activities like collecting Ancient Bones or Salvageable Scrap, but yielding less units as a tradeoff for a decent amount of nanites, scaling with your mining speed. (The procedural Loot treasure appears intended to be the reward in vanilla also, but seems to not work properly with the vanilla settings).
[/list][/spoiler]
[b][size=3]Recipe Changes[/size][/b]
[spoiler]
[list]
[*]Several simple "[b]infinite loops[/b]" that don't consume any "catalyst" resources [b]no longer can give infinite product without consuming something[/b].
[*]Overall, refining should no longer be the easiest/fastest way to get materials by a wide margin, although still quite useful and worthwhile. On the other hand, various vanilla refining recipes which used to be plainly inferior to alternatives have been improved to now yield enough output to actually be worthwhile.
[*]Refining Chromatic Metal with Stellar Metals (Copper, Indium, etc.) to make more Stellar Metals now costs the "[b]proper[/b]" amount of Chromatic Metal, so you cannot get [b]infinite Stellar Metals[/b] this way.
[*]In general, most refiner recipes which take a "[b]desired[/b]" substance + a common "catalyst" substance to produce more of the "[b]desired[/b]" substance, only yield "[b]reasonable[/b]" amounts of the "[b]desired[/b]" substance instead of increasing it by ~6x. E.G. instead of in vanilla where [b]2 Salt + 2 Oxygen = 5 Chlorine[/b], now [b]2 Salt + 2 Oxygen = 3 Chlorine[/b]
[*]For these same recipes, in general I have made a trend where using the "[b]low tier[/b]" version of the recipe [b]more efficiently[/b] produces the "[b]desired[/b]" substance, while using the "[b]high tier[/b]" version of the recipe is less efficient, but creates the product [b]much more quickly[/b]. For example, now [b]2 Salt + 2 Oxygen = 3 Chlorine[/b] in 90 time units, but [b]2 Chlorine[/b] (which is worth 4 Salt) [b]+ 2 Oxygen = 4 Chlorine[/b] in 60 time units. This makes choosing which version of a recipe to use more meaningful, and indirectly makes mining/harvesting by hand more rewarding, since typically mining/harvesting by hand yields the "[b]low tier[/b]" substance (e.g. Carbon), while most refiner recipes will output the "[b]high tier[/b]" substance (e.g. Condensed Carbon).

[*] ﻿ ﻿Also, several refiner recipes for creating either [b]Hyperfuel [/b]or [b]Platinum [/b]which normally require 250 Chromatic Metal now only require [b]10 or 15[/b] so that the recipes are actually worth considering.

[*]Also buffed the [b]Atlantideum [/b]+ [b]Mordite [/b]--> [b]Living Slime[/b] recipe, as on top of taking an extraordinarily long time, it was vastly less efficient at converting Atlantideum into Runaway Mould than simply using some of the Atlantideum to create Pugneum and make Runaway Mould directly. It now completes [b]120x faster[/b], and is ~[b]20x more efficient[/b], but makes [b]Residual Goop[/b] instead of Living Slime. This makes it a bit more efficient, but require more time & steps than the alternative (Atlantideum + Pugneum --> Runaway Mould)
[*]Making [b]Frost Crystals[/b] into [b]Glass [/b]by using the [b]Refiner [/b]now takes [b]0.5x[/b] as long and uses [b]0.75x[/b] as much Frost Crystal instead of the same amount as crafting it directly in the inventory, so it now is worthwhile to do.
[*]Refining the other 5 biome-specific crops (all except Frost Crystal) into Carbon now yields [b]~0.63x[/b] as much Carbon, and takes [b]1.4x[/b] as long to process
[*]Refining [b]Deuterium [/b]from Di-Hydrogen + Silicate Powder now requires [b]5x[/b] Silicate Powder
