[*] ﻿ [b]﻿14 recipes[/b] for yielding [b]Salvaged Data[/b] by refining items which can yield Nanites when refined ([b]Runaway Mould, Tainted Metal[/b], [b]Larval Core, Hadal Core, Vile Spawn, Flesh Rope, Radiant Shard, Inverted Mirror, Hyaline Brain, Quad Servo, Hardframe Engine, Crystallised Heart, Walker Brain, [/b]or [b]Sea Glass[/b]) with Microprocessors. ﻿This works out to effectively getting 1 Salvaged Data in exchange for 50 Nanites & either some crafting materials or 25k/50k Units (depending on if you buy your Microprocessors on-planet vs. a space station). So it is not especially efficient, but an option for those who prefer to spend some Units / Nanites rather than hunt for Damaged Machinery on planets.
[*]The [b]in-game descriptions[/b] for any items which can be refined into [b]nanites [/b]or [b]Salvaged Data[/b] should now note this, as well as notes for Gravitino Balls, Basalt, etc. for their new refiner recipes (As well as in-game hints in descriptions for [b]Sea Glass[/b] and "[b]Junk[/b]" items how they can be refined into more useful items). The in-game [b]recipe list[/b] should display accurate versions of any existing recipes modified by PTSd, and the names of the 29 new recipes added by PTSd begin with "[b]PTSd: [/b]" for easy recognition.
[*]Refining [b]Radiant Shards[/b], [b]Inverted Mirrors[/b], or [b]Hyaline Brains[/b] into Nanites yields only[b] 0.32x, 0.5x, and 0.37x as many Nanites[/b], respectively.
[*]Crafting Creature Pellets by hand makes [b]3 Pellets instead of 5[/b]. However, all Nutrient Processor recipes for making Creature Pellets now also make [b]3 Pellets per recipe[/b] instead of vanilla's 1, to make them still superior to crafting by hand. 
[*]While Cooking hasn't been covered in depth by PTSd (it's a little all over the place), a "[b][s]light[/s] medium pass[/b]" has been done for [b]Nutrient Processor recipes[/b]:
[*] ﻿ ﻿Recipes which take a substance which is easy to passively collect in bulk to make a cooking ingredient [b]now cost 25x of that substance[/b]. This includes all [b]farmable plants[/b] into their respective ingredient forms, and [b]Chromatic Metal[/b] (for Silicon Eggs).
[*] ﻿ ﻿Similarly, recipes for [b]Creature Pellets[/b] which use the farmable plants [b]require 5x of each plant[/b], or for the Carbon recipe, [b]20x the Carbon.[/b]
[*] ﻿ ﻿Making [b]Marrow Flesh[/b] from Marrow Bulbs, or [b]Kelp Rice[/b] from Kelp Sacs, or [b]Meat Flakes[/b] from Mordite, or [b]Wild Yeast[/b] from Faecium, or [b]Crunchy Caramel/Salty Custard/Salty Juice [/b]from Salt, or various [b]Ice Creams[/b] from Frost Crystals, or [b]Smoked Meat [/b]from Carbon/Condensed Carbon, all [b]require 5x of the substance[/b] (2x for Condensed Carbon) now.
[*] ﻿ ﻿Overall these changes make it more costly to try to produce lots of high-value foods without doing any harvesting of [b]wild ingredient plants[/b] or [b]animal products[/b].
[*] ﻿ ﻿The new [b]"worm" foods[/b] cooked from [b]Flesh Rope[/b] have had their[b] value increased roughly 10x[/b] to make them actually worthwhile to cook, since many of their ingredients can instead be refined into Nanites or sold raw for large amounts of units. The Hypnotic Eye was moved from an ingredient in the tier 2 "worm" food to the tier 3 food, since in PTSd it is considerably more valuable than the other raw ingredients. Other recipes using Hypnotic Eyes have similarly had their value increased ~2x to compensate.
[*] ﻿ ﻿[b]Juicy Grub[/b] value increased [b]6x[/b] and cooking it now yields [b]16x[/b] Nourishing Slime, so it is less of a loss to cook it
[*] ﻿ ﻿[b]Herbal Crunchie[/b] requires [b]1[/b] more [b]Processed Sugar[/b] to cook, and no longer can be made with [b]Geknip [/b]instead of [b]NipNip Buds[/b], as that would lose money in PTSd
[*] ﻿ ﻿[b]Baked Eggs, Delicate Meringue, & Soft Custard Fancy[/b] can no longer be made with [b]Larval Cores[/b], as this loses money even in vanilla. Similarly, the alternative recipes for [b]Cake of the Lost[/b] or [b]Abyssal Stew[/b] that use [b]2 Larval Cores[/b] / [b]Hypnotic Eyes[/b] instead of 1 have been removed.
[*] ﻿ ﻿Similar changes to alternative recipes for [b]Cake of Eternal Sleep[/b], [b]Syrup-Drenched Delight[/b], and [b]Bone Broth[/b] to avoid cases where one version of a recipe is significantly less profitable.
[*][b]Refined Flour's[/b] CookingValue lowered from 1.8 to [b]0.18[/b] as presumably this was a typo in vanilla (all other CookingValues are 1.0 or less). This affects both the nanites Cronus awards for it and also the strength of its Nutrient Ingestor bonus
[*][b]Iced Screams[/b] and [b]Syrupy Viscera[/b] now give a bonus to [b]Words Translated[/b] in the [b]Nutrient Ingestor[/b], like most other foods cooked with Hypnotic Eyes
[*]Some broad [b]rebalancing [/b]on the [b]units value [/b]of many [b]cooked foods[/b] based on their "[b]type[/b]"/"[b]main ingredient[/b]". Very roughly brings many other foods types closer to the balance point of Doughnut type foods in vanilla, in terms of units value for ingredients used:
[*] ﻿ ﻿﻿[b]Sugar Dough[/b] foods (Biscuits) value are now [b]0.55x[/b]
[*] ﻿[b]Pie Case[/b] foods (Pies) value are now [b]0.8x[/b]
[*] [b]Wailing Batter[/b] (Larval Core) foods are now [b]0.9x[/b]
[*] [b]Writhing, Roiling Batter[/b] (Larval Core) foods are now [b]0.92x[/b]
[*] [b]Doughnut[/b] foods value are now [b]1.15x[/b]
[*] [b]Proto Batter[/b] foods value are now [b]1.15x[/b]
[*] ﻿[b]﻿Ice Cream [/b]foods value are now [b]1.23x[/b]
[*][b] ﻿ ﻿Cake Batter[/b] foods value are now ~[b]1.28x[/b]
[*][b] ﻿﻿Thick, Sweet [b]Batter[/b] foods value are now [b]1.25x[/b][/b]
[*][b][b] ﻿ [b]Syrupy[b] [/b][/b][b][b] Batter[/b] foods value are now [b]1.25x[/b][/b][/b][/b]
[*] [b]Extra Fluffy Batter[/b] foods value are now [b]2.1x[/b]
[*] Some foods in these groups were [b]individually adjusted[/b] if the above changes made them especially over/under valued
[*] This rebalancing takes into consideration that [b]Milk [/b]& [b]Eggs[/b] are inherently more valuable than [b]Flour [/b]& [b]Sugar[/b], as they cannot be bulk-refined from farmable crops. Also makes it more consistent that [b]Sticky 'Honey', Synthetic Honey, [/b]& [b]Syrupy Nectar[/b] add significant value to foods (their descriptions now note this). Cooked food value balance is still pretty loose overall, but many of the major "trees" of recipes are a bit closer together now.
[*] ﻿ ﻿Value of foods cooked with [b]fish [/b]are balanced around always using the [b]cheapest fish possible[/b]. Generally this means that usually only [b]Common [/b](C Class) fish are worthwhile to cook [b]alone [/b]in most cases, and usually ﻿just [b]Small Common[/b] fish if [b]combining [/b]with other fish / ingredients. Exceptions for most Uncommon (B) Colossal fish (aside from Giant Sunray) and the various species-specific recipes for species which don't come in Common and/or Small varieties like turtles, squid, octopus, starfish, eels, etc. 
[*][b]2 new Nutrient Processor recipes[/b] have also been added:
[*] ﻿ ﻿2x [b]Steamed Vegetables[/b] ﻿from ﻿1x Aloe Flesh ﻿+ ﻿1x Condensed Carbon ﻿ ﻿(in Vanilla Aloe Flesh & Refreshing Drink are not that useful)
[*] ﻿ ﻿1x [b]Cream[/b] ﻿ ﻿ ﻿ ﻿from ﻿1x Refreshing Drink ﻿+ ﻿1x Refined Flour ﻿ ﻿(Makes Aloe Flesh more useful, since Cream is a component of most valuable foods. As a side effect, technically allows for "vegan" versions of any recipes requiring dairy products.)
[/list][/spoiler]
[b][size=3]General Difficulty Changes[/size][/b]
[spoiler]
[list]
[*]Various individual things not covered in the Difficulty Settings menu which used to be more difficult in Survival Mode but got "[b]normalized[/b]" in [b]NMS 4.0[/b] have their [b]base values changed[/b] to be back near their [b]pre-4.0 Survival Mode[/b] levels. Specifically: 
[*] ﻿ ﻿Refining times, Chances of a planet having "low" sentinel activity, removal of "no-sentinel" planets, cargo value levels to attract scans from pirate/sentinel ships, Scanner pulse cooldown & range, how quickly sentinels may spawn near you if none are nearby, Multi-Tool mining laser heating & cooling profile, certain enemy spawn amounts, etc. 
[*]Because PTSd raises the base challenge of various aspects of the game, the individual effects of various [b]difficulty settings[/b] have been tweaked so that "[b]standard/normal[/b]" options for most difficulty options reflects the [b]base PTSd experience[/b], more or less equivalent to playing the previous version of PTSd on Survival mode pre-4.0. Then, changing various difficulty options to "[b]Low/Cheap/Slow/[/b]etc." will be an [b]easier[/b] version of PTSd, and changing them to "[b]High/Expensive/Fast[/b]/etc." will be an even [b]harder [/b]version of PTSd.
[*] ﻿ ﻿The exact value changes made by various difficulty settings, and an explanation of their effects can be seen in [b]"PTSD Other Difficulty Settings.lua"[/b] However, PTSd [b]now updates most in-game preset & difficulty setting descriptions[/b] with a more in-depth explanation of their effects, including any relevant numbers or unintuitive side-effects.
[*] ﻿ ﻿E.G. PTSd's "[b]Standard[/b]" setting for "Survival Difficulty" has the same base Hazard & Life Support drain rates as the older version of PTSds. This is however several times faster than the Vanilla "[b]Standard[/b]" or "[b]Challenging[/b]" settings. The PTSd "[b]Relaxed[/b]" setting reduces the Hazard drain rate to 33% of the "Normal" PTSd rate (which is in between the Vanilla "Normal" & "Challenging" rates), and the PTSd "Challenging" setting increases it to 150% of the "Normal" PTSd rate.
[*] ﻿ ﻿The "[b]Normal[/b]" difficulty preset has options set to be a basic "[b]PTSd-Lite[/b]", with most of the same settings as the "Survival" preset, but a few keys things made easier (such as incoming damage & hazard drain rate lowered by at least half). Setting additional options to easier, or using the "[b]Relaxed[/b]" preset will make it even easier, approaching vanilla-level challenge.
[*]The [b]presets [/b]for the various "default" difficulty settings have been changed to reflects this. E.G. selecting the "[b]Survival[/b]" preset will now set most options to "Standard/Normal" (Since "[b]Standard[/b]" PTSd is still more challenging than "[b]Survival[/b]" vanilla) and is the "base" PTSd experience, how I usually play & test it. The in-game descriptions of the different difficulty presets should briefly state how they fit with PTSd.
[*]By setting most difficulty options to the "Low/Easy" setting, you should be able to get an overall challenge that is closer to the vanilla range, while still benefitting from all the balance tweaks, improved activity rewards, bug fixes, new features, etc. of PTSd. In particular, [b]if you dislike the smaller inventory sizes in PTSd, [/b]setting the [b]Stack Limit[/b] setting on the highest will allow all slots to hold more of both Substances [b]and Products[/b], allowing total storage closer to vanilla.
[*]Notably, you now should be able to both decrease & increase the [b]Stack Limit[/b] settings in-game instead of only when creating a new save. Note that when doing so, you will lose any items from any existing stacks which are larger than the new stack limit, so split your stacks into smaller stacks beforehand and perhaps back up your save to test it out first.
[*]Some of the [b]Difficulty Setting descriptions[/b] also contain relevant notes on [b]important gameplay features[/b] or [b]tips [/b]for PTSd.
[*]Many Difficulty settings in [b]Expeditions [/b]can now be [b]lowered 1 step lower[/b] than is normally possible in vanilla if desired, to offset PTSd's increased overall difficulty for users who want a challenge closer to vanilla during an Expedition. (can be toggled off at the top of "[b]PTSd Other Difficulty Settings.lua[/b]")
[*][b]Foods [/b]which restored between [b]1~3 health[/b] when consumed directly (most raw meat, most small cooked fish, etc.) now only restore [b]1 health[/b]. Foods restored [b]3 health[/b] when consumed directly (certain more complicated dishes, most larger cooked fish, etc.) now restore [b]2 health[/b]. Most raw meat and small cooked fish now note in their description that they can be consumed directly to restore some health.
[*][b]Ion Batteries[/b] cost [b]2x [/b]as much Cobalt & Ferrite Dust to craft.
[*][b]Autonomous Mining Units[/b] require [b]3x[/b] Ion Batteries to build
[*][b]Starship Launch Fuel[/b] now costs [b]1.5x[/b] Di-Hydrogen and[b] 2x[/b] Metal Plating to craft, and comes in [b]~0.5x[/b] the amount from Space Station Mission rewards
[*]Starships cost twice as much Launch Fuel to [b]summon [/b]than to lift off manually on all "Fuel Usage" difficulty settings. On the "Expensive" setting, this means that without upgrades only Explorer or Shuttle ships can initially afford to be summoned (apart from the 1 "free" summon you get each time you load your save). However installing the "Efficient Thrusters" tech is enough to allow other starships to be able to be summoned on the "Expensive" setting.
[*]The [b]temporary teleporters[/b] to return you to a [b]Corvette [/b]from a planet's surface now cost [b]1 Navigation Data[/b] to "unlock" them for that specific location (can keep re-using the same temporary teleporter without paying additional Nav Data, but moving the Corvette to a new location will spawn a new temporary teleporter which will cost 1 Nav Data to "unlock"). So instead of never landing and getting around for free, the intended method in PTSd is to either land normally or spend 1 Nav Data to allow multiple teleport trips at a particular spot. Since teleporting down is always free, if you realize you have no Nav Data the Corvette can always be freely summoned down to the surface if it is currently hovering in atmosphere.
[*] ﻿ ﻿ ﻿(This can be toggled off with [i]CovetteTeleportCost [/i]in [b]PTSd More Expensive Costs etc.lua[/b] and recompiling with AMUMSS, or by simply deleting [b]No Man's Sky\GAMEDATA\MODS\PTSd Prices and Tech etc\MODELS\COMMON\SPACECRAFT\BIGGS\TELEPORTER\ENTITIES\TELEPORTER.ENTITY.MBIN[/b])
[*]Thanks to an adaptation of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/1777]gDamage - Damage Difficulty Mod﻿ by Gumsk[/url]﻿, the [b]base[/b] [b]damage to the player from all sources is significantly increased[/b].
[*]Aside from damage increases, the ﻿"[b]Exploding gas plant[/b]" Hazardous Flora on planet surfaces have their explosion AOE radius increased[b] 1.33x[/b]
[*]Thanks to an adaptation of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/1275]Exosolar's Savage Sentinels﻿ by ExoSolar & Babscoole[/url]﻿, [b]all planetary Sentinels have increased health, firerate, mobility, speed, & aggression in combat[/b]. Drones also have double the range on most weapons, so they can attack the player while you are moving or retreating. While they are also more difficult to run away from now due to their increased speed, they will also search for the player for a longer time at the low "wanted" levels.
[*]In particular, Sentinel Mechs should have an easier time hitting the player, with longer range, more spread, longer/faster bursts, and increased projectile speed on their weapons.
[*]Additional Sentinel spawns have been added, such as Sentinel Quads during Wanted Level 4, guarding Manufacturing facilities & Sentinel Pillars, Summoner Drones guarding Planetary Harvesters, or chances to have slightly more or less Corrupted Drones during Settlement attacks. 
[*]Also, passive (non-hostile) Sentinel drones have had their [b]crime vision radius, patrol area, and "investigation" duration increased[/b], and most planets have an [b]additional Patrol Drone[/b] to make it more difficult to keep sneaking some mining in around them. 
[*]However, this is partially offset by all Sentinel Patrol Drones spawning farther away from the player, which allows landing & moving on Aggressive Sentinel planets without being detected with enough caution / stealth. 
[*][b]Sentinels [/b]on [b]Corrupted planets[/b] have received particular attention, including revamping the types and numbers of sentinels spawn at different [b]Wanted Levels[/b], culminating in a fight against 3 large Arachnid sentinels with ~5 Corrupted Drone and mini-Arachnids as backup simultaneously. This is intended to be the peak of on-planet combat, on par with fighting a Sentinel Walker, and assumes the player has access to late-game options such as an S Class combat Multi-tool with many upgrades, a Minotaur under AI-pilot, combos of Voltaic Amplifier with stun sources, etc.
[*]﻿The [b]health [/b]of [b]Dissonance Resonators[/b] on Corrupt Planets has been increased [b]5x[/b], to make it harder to simply use "hit & run" tactics to quickly take them out without engaging with or taking damage from nearby sentinels. 
[*]Similar to vanilla, choosing the "[b]Minimal[/b]" or "[b]Hostile[/b]" setting for "[b]Space Combat[/b]" in the difficulty menu will decrease / increase the base Hull & Shield health of enemy ships amount by -34% / +33%, stacking multiplicatively with the "Enemy Strength" difficulty setting.
[*]Thanks to an adaptation of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/1537]Space Combat Reworked - and Larger Space Battles﻿ by Xaliber13[/url]﻿, all NPC starships (& freighters/frigates) have significantly increased combat abilities such as health, firerate, speed, etc. Additionally, the number of enemy & ally starships in most space encounters has been substantially increased, with greater variation of player Squadron pilot abilities between Class ranks. Also, the boosting speed of enemy ships has been increased to match the speed buff the player can get by diverting power to engines, to make escaping pirates as difficult as before.
[*]And thanks to [url=https://forums.nexusmods.com/index.php?showtopic=8651053/#entry91396313]further adjustments to Space Combat Reworked﻿ by Estel1[/url]﻿, all NPC starships/freighters (both enemy & ally) do significantly ﻿more damage to one another. So while enemy starships are stronger, having allied / neutral starships / freighters nearby will make a much bigger difference in battles.
[*]The delay between waves of increasing Wanted Levels in space during which you can again use your Pulse Jump / Hyperdrive increased from 3 sec to 12 sec.
[*]Additionally, enemy ship difficulty should scale better according to mission / encounter difficulty, with wider variations between "Easy" and "Hard" variations of enemy ships, more types of enemy ship shields/engines, etc. E.G. Now Trader ships have huge, very slow to regenerate shields (6x the size of "Standard" shields), but very little Hull health and handle poorly in space, while their Escort ships have much more HP and very small, quickly recharging shields, and handle very well in space.
[*]While the overall [b]chance of Tech Damage[/b] per hit is [b]reduced [/b]roughly in half in PTSd to compensate for the higher rate of enemy attacks, the chance per hit of Tech Damage in your starship is reduced a further [b]50%[/b] due to the very fast fire rate of enemy ships. The protection against Tech Damage that shields provide while still active is also increased in PTSd .
[*]Thanks to a modified version of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/1775]gCreatures Predators - Difficulty Mod[/url]﻿ and [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/1839]gCreatures Predators Frequency - Difficulty Mod[/url]﻿ by Gumsk, [b]predators are more aggressive[/b] towards the player and [b]spawn more frequently[/b], including some [b]underwater sharks[/b] being hostile. (However, this has been edited to remove the feature which causes planets to replace a certain amount of passive species with predators, in order to maintain "species sync" with vanilla players.) Predators are now all [b]more active at night[/b], so they should appear less often during the day. 
[*]﻿[b]Hungering Tendril[/b] / [b]Titan Worm[/b] health increased [b]3x, "Eyeball" Abyssal Horror [/b]health increased[b] 6x, [/b]and [b]"Anglerfish" Abyssal Horror [/b]health increased[b] 3x. [/b]"Anglerfish" also deal more damage on the initial "explosion" and spawn more "Jellyfish" when appearing.
[*][b]Vile Queen[/b] health increased [b]2x[/b], helper bugs health increased [b]~3x[/b], and the range, amount, and explosive AOE of her spit attack is significantly increased
[*]Your exosuit's maximum Tech Inventory has been [b]reduced from 60 to 40[/b]. 
[*]While I could not edit it directly, PTSd is balanced around [b]only upgrading your Exosuit Cargo inventory to 40 slots[/b] instead of 120. This makes using exocraft / starships (with buffed teleporter range) / the freighter for storage more important.
[*]Thanks to adaptations of portions of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/1626]gExo's Challenge Modpack﻿ by Exosolar & Gumsk[/url]﻿, on a new game start (and when core-jumping to a new galaxy), [b]you start about ~6x as far away from your crashed starship[/b] as in vanilla.
[*]Additionally, all [b]"Approximate Locations" are 4x ~ 10x farther away[/b] from their target locations for missions using the "[b]Target Sweep[/b]" function (Use an alternate module in the "Optional Files" section to use vanilla distances instead). Now it should be harder to simply see the target building as you land your spaceship, but instead may need to make use of riding companions / exocraft more often. PTSd also increases the maximum distance away that your Target Sweep Visor will give accurate distance info, so it's less important to start right at the indicated landing spot. If the game places the initial landing spot in a bad location, try saving & reloading the game which should re-roll a new random landing spot. (The 5 "Rendezvous" locations for Expeditions are unaffected, although you can manually change those under the 5 "SurveyDistance" entries in the SEASON_DATA_CACHE.JSON file within your save folder).
[*]Thanks to an adaptation of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/1626]gExo's Challenge[/url]﻿, [b]storms are slightly longer and more frequent[/b]. On Extreme Weather planets however, they are much longer and more frequent.
[*][b]Tornadoes [/b]are more common, and more commonly come in clusters.
[*]Hazards (Hot, Cold, Toxic, Radiation) now [b]drain your Hazard protection roughly three times as fast[/b] (including holding your breath underwater), and will damage your shield/health more rapidly once your hazard protection runs out. Additionally, the procedural Upgrade Modules for Hot/Cold/Toxic/Radiation which provide full protection for a set time, now only [b]last ~1/2 as long[/b]. This makes going into hazard without protective tech/upgrades more dangerous, especially underwater. Also makes the "3x slower hazard drain" from being inside an exocraft more appealing before unlocking the Minotaur or hazard immunity techs for other exocraft. 
[*] ﻿﻿PTSd uses a weakened version of the new Vanilla feature where your hazard bar drains much slower at the start and early parts of a new game. In PTSd, this means at the start of a new game (up until you have a scanner tech installed on a multi-tool) your hazard bar drains three times as slowly, and then from then until you first reach your starship it drains 1.8x as slowly as the rest of the game.
[*]To compensate, all of the %-based Hazard protection [b]tech & upgrades now provide stronger protection[/b]: 24% instead of 20% for Shield Lattice, 38% instead of 20% for the biome-specific techs, and 10%~24% instead of 1%~10% for the Class X upgrades (The Underwater %-based protection tech is incredibly strong in particular, nearly doubling your breath time). These %-based tech & upgrades all stack multiplicatively with each other, and the Class X Suspicious Hazard protections gain huge adjacency bonuses (easily doubling in power when fully surrounded). All of them aside from the Shield Lattice also gain enormous benefits from supercharging. Overall this should make dedicating some resources and inventory slots to preparing for hazards more important & useful.
[*]The way that each planet biome differs from the default hazard intensity in various situations has been been adjusted. The [b]daytime/nighttime[/b] effects of increasing/decreasing the hazard intensity on [b]Cold & Hot[/b] planets mirror each other more closely now. Being [b]underwater [/b]on [b]Hot [/b]planets provides less protection from the heat, and the effects of going [b]underwater [/b]on [b]Radioactive [/b]& [b]Toxic[/b] planets have been reversed from vanilla. [b]Radioactive water[/b] is milder since water is an excellent method of blocking harmful radiation in real life, and [b]Toxic water[/b] is harsher since water/liquids are a famous method of conveying toxic/corrosive chemicals.
[*]In particular, [b]Gas Giants[/b] now have [b]constant hazard effects of all kinds[/b]: [b]high heat[/b] during the day, underwater, or in storms, then [b]freezing cold[/b] at night due to the different unmixed gases swirling around. There are also constant, [b]low level[/b] [b]toxins [/b]& [b]radiation[/b] in all environments outside of caves due to the types of gases in the air & the exotic materials being crushed. Unlike other planets, even being [b]underground [/b]or in [b]caves [/b]will still have a slight cold drain from trapped gases. 
[*] ﻿In practice, this means that while you still may want to use a [b]rechargeable hazard protection upgrade module[/b] for [b]Heat [/b]& [b]Cold [/b]for storms on gas giants or on extreme gas giants, it's also useful to have decent [b]%-based hazard protection[/b] for [b]Toxin [/b]& [b]Radiation [/b](since those hazards are weak enough that your base hazard protection will last a decent amount of time, and you'll only need to use half as many resources / Ion Batteries that way)
[*]It takes ~[b]1.13x/1.5x[/b] as much substances to recharge your Hazard/Life Support bars, and the procedural Hazard Protection upgrade modules require [b]2x [/b]the substances to recharge. (Running out of Life Support will also damage your shield / health much more rapidly)
[*][b]Phosphorus [/b]is now only [b]0.6x[/b] as effective at recharging the [b]Mining Laser[/b] / [b]Hijacked Laser[/b] / [b]Runic Lens[/b]
[*][b]Dioxite [/b]is now only [b]0.6x[/b] as effective at recharging [b]Life Support[/b]
[*]Additionally, [b]regular starships[/b] require [b]1.5x [/b]the [b]Sodium/Sodium Nitrate[/b] to recharge their Shields, [b]6x[/b] the [b]Uranium [/b]to recharge their Launch thrusters, and [b]1.25x[/b] the [b]Tritium / ~12x[/b] the [b]Pyrite[/b] to recharge the Pulse Engine. 
[*][b]Living Ships[/b] require [b]2x[/b] the substance to recharge their Hyperdrive and can now use [b]Processed Meat[/b] properly, however they only require [b]0.38x[/b] the substance to recharge their Shields and [b]0.75x[/b] the Mordite or [b]1.5x[/b] the Oxygen/Condensed Carbon to recharge their Launch Thrusters. All of these changes should give greater incentive to invest in the dedicated recharging consumable items, which are unchanged.
[*][b]Sentinel Interceptors[/b] require [b]0.5x[/b] as much Pugneum to recharge their launcher, [b]1.25x[/b] as much Tritium to recharge their pulse drive, and [b]1.5x[/b] as much Sodium Nitrate to recharge their shields.
[*]"Regular" charts at a Space Station Cartographer now [b]cost 2x Navigation Data[/b], Settlement Charts now[b] cost 1.6x[/b], and Exosuit Upgrade Charts [b]cost 42[/b] instead of 3 Navigation Data.
[*]Most items (Substances, Consumables, or Components for crafting/repairing/installing) now [b]cost up to twice as much to buy on a Space Station[/b] as planetside, in addition to any changes below. This includes buying Class X upgrade modules at an Outlaw Station (with nanites) vs. buying off a landed smuggler pilot on a planet.
[*][b]Most Substances cost 20x as much[/b] to buy as vanilla. (Tritium is additionally worth 6x as much as vanilla) ﻿This means that buying substances (especially from Space Stations) is done more as an emergency or a luxury instead of the primary way of obtaining resources.
[*][b]Most Consumables cost 5x as much[/b] to buy as vanilla (the 200 unit ones like Ion Batteries or Di-Hydrogen Jelly instead cost [b]150x [/b]as much as vanilla, with Life Support Gel costing [b]~300x[/b])
[*][b]Most Components (For Repairing/Installing) cost ~10x [/b]as much to buy as vanilla
[*] ﻿(A side effect of the above 3 changes is that now the displayed "Demand" for those items will incorrectly be listed as ~half of what it actually is. E.G. the game may display "Demand: -50%" when the item is actually selling for full price (100%))
[*]At [b]Outlaw Stations[/b], Goods Packets cost increased by [b]3x[/b], Tech & Weapons Packets cost increased by [b]10x[/b], and Larval & Hadal Cores now cost [b]2x [/b]their base value (which was also increased).
[*]NipNip Buds now cost [b]16x [/b]their base value to purchase instead of 3x. Starting a NipNip farm either requires a large initial investment, or luck in finding the first few buds to grow.
[*]Squadron Pilot slots cost ~[b]1.5x[/b] more nanites to unlock.
[*]Asking a [b]Traveller [/b]at a Space Station for [b]directions [/b]to a grave now costs [b]8x[/b] as much Nanites.
[*]The "[b]black orbs[/b]" on pedestals in the first few [b]Atlas Stations[/b] on the Atlas Path missions now yield [b]Antimatter [/b]instead of Warp Cells, with a 50% chance to yield 80 nanites instead.
[*][b]Emergency Signal Scanners[/b] start costing 6mil instead of 5mil (although this is offset in that a Derelict freighter will typically yield more units than in vanilla), and [b]continue increasing in price up to 64mil[/b] after the twelfth purchase of the day. There is also a small chance for high-level Space Station or Outlaw Station missions to offer one as a reward.
[*]Amounts of [b]claimable supplies[/b] in the airlock entrance room of [b]Derelict Freighters[/b] reduced roughly by [b]half [/b]Notably, this includes the 3 Repair Kits normally claimable in the crate now being 1-2 (~1.5 on average)
[*][b]Walker Brains are less common[/b] of a gift from Guild Envoys
[*][b]Frigate Expedition difficulty is increased substantially[/b]: it takes twice as many "stat points" to reach most of the "star ratings" for fleet strength (three times as many points to reach 5 star rating), and the encounter difficulty of missions has been increased to match (the cap on maximum fleet rating has likewise been increased). Also, missions can appear up to 4 star difficulty rating, not just 3 stars. The 3 & 4 star difficulty rating missions are substantially more difficult than the others, and will likely require highly ranked frigates and significant frigate-boosting freighter upgrade modules to accomplish without risking damage. Like in vanilla, sending a fleet with a star rating at least 2 stars above the difficulty rating of the expedition should always result in no damage to the fleet.
[*]The base "Fleet Coordination" stat for Freighters, and strength of the various Frigate-boosting upgrade modules have had their [b]power reduced to ~33% of vanilla[/b]. However with adjacency bonuses they still become quite powerful when stacked.
[*]You now drop [b]50,000 units[/b] on death instead of 5,000 units. 
[*]Repairing the [b]Pilot Interface[/b] for a crashed [b]Sentinel Interceptor[/b] is significantly [b]more expensive[/b], costing [b]2x[/b] the Inverted Mirrors & Radiant Shards, and also requiring [b]2 Starship AI Valves[/b]. However in PTSd Starship AI Valves can now be bought in Space Stations, or slightly cheaper from Planetary Archives / Minor Settlements, for about 13,000,000 units (would be even cheaper to keep any you've scrapped yourself vs. buying any).  This means that on average a Sentinel Interceptor will [b]cost a similar price in units[/b] to a conventional starship of the same size at B/A Class, but depending on the Class you find it could be a better or worse deal.
[*]Similarly, repairing [b]broken slots on Sentinel Multi-Tools[/b] will now always cost [b]2x Recycled Circuitry & 1x Semiconductor[/b] in addition to the normal cost. Recycled Circuitry can now be purchased just like Starship AI Valves, though Semiconductors must either be found through exploration/mission rewards or crafted yourself,  costing about [b]1,900,000 in total per slot[/b] repaired. It should work out that fully repairing the slots on a Sentinel Multi-Tool incurs a cost roughly similar to purchasing a new Experimental / Alien tool of middle Class with the same size, however like Sentinel Interceptors the cost will be the same regardless of the class of the tool. The main difference being part of the cost must be found / crafted, and that it doesn't need to be paid up front to start using the tool right away, sort of a "[b]buy now, pay later[/b]" option. 
[*] ﻿ ﻿(If using Repair Kits instead of normal components to repair these slots, each Recycled Circuitry requires its own Repair Kit so as to increase the cost of taking this approach. As a side effect, ﻿you will have to enter the full zoomed-in "repairing" UI to see the full list of required components, as the Inventory UI overview only displays the first 3 required components)
[*]Greatly [b]increased[/b] the crafting requirements for the [b]craftable Voltaic Staff components[/b]. Now each of the 3 parts requires at least ~1.5 million units worth of [b]Recycled Circuitry[/b] (purchasable from most trade terminals in PTSd), as well as higher numbers of Radiant Shards, etc. This should incentivize instead collecting Void Motes to buy the purchasable Staff components, and makes it less feasible to craft your own Staff just to salvage it for a profit.
[*]﻿Increased cost of [b]Rebuilt Exosuit Modules[/b] by [b]2.5x[/b] (bought with Void Motes.
[*]﻿Disturbing [b]Vigilant Eyes[/b] is less likely to spawn the floating [b]Living Stones[/b] compared to the [b]Golem Mechs[/b], always spawns [b]at least 2[/b] when it spawns the Living Stones, and can now sometimes spawn the Golem & Living Stones [b]together[/b]. This also indirectly slightly increases the yield of Vigilant Stones, as Golems are more likely to drop them than Living Stones.
[*][b]Overhaul [/b]to increase [b]Pirate Dreadnought[/b] battle difficulty & rewards, overview below:
[*] ﻿﻿The battle is more of a true "[b]race against time[/b]" / "[b]DPS check[/b]" now, with the role of the Anti-Freighter Cannons & Pirate Frigates essentially swapped from vanilla. In PTSd it is no longer feasible to destroy the Cannons fast enough to extend the battle, so the civilian freighter will essentially be taking constant slow damage the whole time. However, you can now destroy most of the Pirate Frigates (the Dreadnought will continually summon replacements once it is down to 2 Frigates) at the start of the battle so that you waste less time taking out the Torpedos, which still need to be continually shot down to prevent the Dreadnought from warping away too soon.
[*] ﻿ ﻿In order of increasing difficulty (& rewards), the ways to succeed at a Dreadnought battle are now:
[*] ﻿ ﻿ ﻿ [b]﻿[/b][b]A)[/b] Deal enough damage (via destroying Exposed Fuel Rods) to cause the Dreadnought to warp away, while the civilian freighter survives, for a "small" bounty. 
[*] ﻿ [b]﻿[/b][b]B)[/b] Fully destroy the Dreadnought (can deal some extra hull damage before destroying the final few Exposed Fuel Rods to prevent it from warping), while the civilian freighter survives, for a "medium" bounty. 
[*] ﻿ [b]﻿[/b][b]C) [/b]Force the Dreadnought to surrender (by destroying the Warp Drives before all the Exposed Fuel Rods) while letting the civilian freighter die, then demanding a "large" tribute from the Dreadnought. 
[*] ﻿ [b]﻿[/b][b]D)[/b] Force the Dreadnought to surrender as in C, but do it fast enough that the civilian freighter survives, then collect both the "medium" bounty and demand a "large" tribute from the Dreadnought (this is difficult to pull off & likely only possible with a fairly late-game setup)
[*] Each of the above success methods requires approximately [b]~1.5x as much damage output / DPS[/b] as the previous method, and the units/nanites reward is roughly [b]~1.5x as valuable[/b] (with more rare items such as [b]Salvaged Frigate Modules[/b] / [b]Cargo Bulkheads[/b], etc.). However even if you fail, you should at least now get a few [b]consolation items[/b] from destroying some Pirate Frigates & most of the destructible parts on the Dreadnought
[*] [b]Claiming [/b]a Pirate Dreadnought now [b]costs 350,000,000 units[/b] instead of being free (still potentially a good deal if the Dreadnought has high slots and Class). However due to modding limitations I haven't found a way around yet, this cost is currently [b]paid each time[/b] you [b]inspect [/b]the Dreadnought, [b]not [/b]when actually confirming the exchange. Added notes about this to the dialogue window to tell the player to [b]use their Analysis Visor instead[/b] to inspect the Dreadnought and decide whether to purchase it (and summon their freighter to uninstall any technology first) [b]before [/b]making the purchase.
[*] [b]Player-controlled[/b] Dreadnought Anti-Freighter Cannons [b]no longer one-shot[/b] unshielded Sentinel Freighters / other Dreadnoughts
[*] Dreadnought battle change [b]specific details[/b]:
[*] ﻿ ﻿Added a few additional Pirate starship spawns to the battle for a little added hazard, however they essentially remain stationary in a cluster where they spawn and act as a sort of turret/obstacle to avoid due to some sort of vanilla pathing issue.
[*] ﻿ ﻿Health for Dreadnought hull increased ~10x, Shield Generators/Exposed Fuel Rods/Anti-Ship Turrets increased ~6x-20x, Anti-Freighter Cannons increased ~30x, and Warp Drives increased ~43x
[*] ﻿ ﻿ ﻿ ﻿Changed Shield Generators in Dreadnought / Sentinel Freighter battles to use the same damage multipliers as starship shields, so anti-shield weapons will work better against them. (added "Shielded" note to their UI name popup in the yellow shield font color to indicate this)
[*] ﻿ ﻿Pirate Frigate health reduced 0.6x, but battle starts with 8 instead of 6 initial Pirate Frigates
[*] ﻿ ﻿Destroying Exposed Fuel Rods now deal 1.12x as much Dreadnought hull damage. Dreadnought attempt to warp away at 16% remaining health instead of 25% remaining health (this breakpoint can still be achieved by destroying all 10 Exposed Fuel Rods)
[*] ﻿ ﻿Dreadnought only summons reinforcement Pirate Frigates when down to 1 remaining Frigate instead of 5. Will now only summon 1 Frigate at a time instead of 3
[*] ﻿ ﻿Dreadnought Anti-Freighter Cannon damage to civilian freighter reduced to ~0.89x, Pirate Frigate Torpedo damage reduced to ~0.77x
[*] ﻿ ﻿Shield Generators now have a chance to drop Starshield Batteries, Warp Drives & Exposed Fuel Rods have a chance to drop Frigate Fuel (50t), Anti-Ship/Freighter Turrets/Cannons drop ~16/~100 Nanites, and Pirate Frigates drop the same loot as "Easy" PTSd Pirate starships.
[*] ﻿Fixed UI countdown for Dreadnought warp to display accurate time remaining, which doesn't actually get increased by destroying Warp Drive likes the vanilla UI shows (apparently a vanilla bug)
[*] Reduced units reward for saving civilian freighter back to vanilla amounts, however added several hundred nanite & a Salvaged Frigate Module or Cargo Bulkhead reward alongside them. Demanding tribute from surrendered Dreadnought units reward increased 1.75x, added ~1,300 nanites, Salvaged Frigate module, & Cargo Bulkhead alongside it
[/list][/spoiler]
[b][size=3]General Balance Changes[/size][/b]
[spoiler]
[list]
[*]﻿[b]Supercharged[/b] tech slot bonus is [b]1.2x[/b] instead of 1.25x
[*]Many generic sources of [b]Substances[/b] now yield [b]0.8x[/b] as much, and [b]Minable objects[/b] in particular yield [b]~0.57x[/b] as much (Miniable objects benefit from potential increases in yield such as the Optical Drill tech, supercharging the Mining Laser core tech for 1.2x yields, or PTSd exclusive bonuses to yield from your Multi-Tool Mining stat)
[*][b]Optical Drill[/b] bonus resource yield is [b]1.33x[/b] instead of 1.5x since it can be supercharged to increase this. Still stacks with the PTSd feature of increased resource yields based on MT mining stat to end up over 3x total yields with a good S Class Pistol and supercharged slots on both the Optical Drill & base Laser tech.
[*]﻿Reduced the bonus Multi-Tool [b]mining yield[/b] during [b]Radiation Storms[/b] from 2.55x to [b]1.75x[/b] of normal substance yield.
[*]﻿Certain outlier [b]underwater plants[/b] & [b]minerals [/b]no longer give [b]incredibly large[/b] (4x-10x more than other similar plants / minerals) amounts of their secondary substance
[*]Strengthened the reduced Sprinting stamina drain effect from [b]Toxic Storms 5x[/b] and the Mining Beam cooling effect from [b]Cold Storms 3x[/b], since these effects are generally much less impactful than the Hot Storm Jetpack efficiency effect or Radiation Storm mining yield effects.
[*]Similarly, the [b]Sub-Light Amplifier[/b] bonus to Pulse Jump Speed reduced to [b]1.25x[/b] from 1.3x, and now requires Cadmium to install.
[*]Reduce﻿d the speed/distance of "[b]Melee-Boosting[/b]" to around [b]~0.66x[/b] of vanilla. 
[*]However to compensate, [b]Rocket Boots[/b] have received [b]several improvements[/b]:
[*] ﻿ ﻿No longer "[b]auto-jump[/b]" when landing/touching terrain while holding spacebar
[*] ﻿ ﻿﻿Increased the [b]speed, height[/b], and [b]duration[/b] of the Rocket Boots effect to roughly [b]~1.3x-1.5x[/b] Vanilla levels. The height increase means it should be much less common to unintentionally "land" prematurely and cut your flight short when trying to Rocket Jump on flat terrain.
[*] ﻿ ﻿The initial "jump" of activating Rocket Boots only depletes the [b]Jetpack Tanks[/b] [b]0.75x[/b] as much as vanilla, though they now deplete [b]1.3x[/b] more quickly for a short period while flying after the initial "jump"
[*] ﻿ ﻿Rocket Boots should now be superior to even the vanilla Melee-Boost for general movement (at the cost of depleting your Jetpack Tanks more quickly and taking up a Tech slot) but still slower overall than Exocraft or a very fast pet (if using the Companion Riding Improvements mod), especially over longer distances.
[*] ﻿ ﻿However, all these changes to Melee-Boosting & Rocket Boots are contained within "[i][b]PTSd Rocket Boots Changes.lua[/b][/i]" if you wish to easily remove them
[*]Thanks to an adaptation of [b][url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/1626]Exosolar & Gumsk's Market Stability[/url]﻿[/b], [b]"market crashing" is no longer viable[/b]. The maximum possible variation for prices due to Supply & Demand or Economy is normally now between ~[b]80%[/b] and ~[b]115%[/b] of an item's base value. (In vanilla prices could be between 20% and 300% due to Supply/Demand, and between 70% and 180% due to Economy). However during a [b]Trade Surge[/b] the maximum selling price increases to [b]~130%[/b] of an item's base value. (Trade Surges only last 1 hour 20 minutes instead of 3 hours) Also, selling items by the player only has [b]~1/30[/b] as much influence on Supply/Demand as in vanilla. (Additionally, since as mentioned above all Substances / Consumables / Components now always cost several times more to buy than to sell, you can never turn a profit by bulk purchasing / reselling them.)
[/list][list]
[*]Thanks to an adaptation of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/1925]Inventory Rebalance﻿ by jackty89[/url]﻿﻿, with the [b]"Restrictive" [/b]stacksize setting as the default, the pattern for both Substance & Product stacksizes [color=#ffffff][/color][color=#ffffff][font=Roboto, sans-serif]at all difficulty settings[/font][/color] is:
[*] ﻿ ﻿[b]Exosuit = 1x, Exocraft = 1.5x, Starships = 2x, Refiners = 2x, Freighter = 4x, Storage = 4x﻿[/b]
[*] ﻿ ﻿This should help make ships/vehicles more appealing for actually helping haul/carry things rather than doing everything yourself. 
[*] ﻿ ﻿The increased stacksize for Refiner input & output slots should make doing bulk refining much less of a hassle also. I.E. You can now place 2 stacks of items from your Exosuit inventory into a Refiner / Nutrient Processor at a time (You can press "X" while hovering over an input slot that already has items in it to keep adding items). Medium & Large Refiners can now be built 4x each in a nearby cluster (still unlimited amount per base, as long as you put a little spacing between clusters)
[*] ﻿ ﻿Additionally, the [b]"Standard"[/b] and [b]"Harsh" [/b]setting now are about [b]~2x[/b] and [b]~0.6x[/b] the "Restrictive" values.
[*][b]Oxygen Recycler[/b] bonus strength buffed from +10% to [b]+36%[/b] (Game patch notes claim this was buffed in Waypoint, but it never was). The recipe for installing Oxygen Recycler now takes [b]1.5x[/b] as much Oxygen, 3 Ion Batteries, and 1 Hermetic Seal (so if doing the tutorial, you must first reach your ship and the 1st building to craft one)
[*]Similarly, increased the shield bonus for the [b]Ablative Armour[/b] starship tech by ~2.6x so it is no longer weaker than Class C Starshield upgrade modules and perhaps now worth unlocking/installing.
[*]Thanks to an adaptation of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/1939]Unique Exocrafts﻿ by jackty89[/url]﻿, all [b]Exocrafts are significantly faster[/b] (roughly 1.5x, but 2.4x for the Nautilon), with a wider variation in attributes such as boost duration/recharge time, vehicle jumping force, or gravity/"airtime". The [b]descriptions [/b]for the different [b]Exocraft Geobays[/b] now note their relative strengths, weaknesses, and [b]special features[/b]. Vehicle fuel usage rate has also been [b]slightly reduced[/b]. This should make vehicles more appealing as an alternative to just always using the ship or jetpacks (or Minotaur jumpjets).
[*]The exception is that the Minotaur has had its fuel usage rate increased 6x to make the fuel techs actually worthwhile on it. However it still has the best fuel efficiency of all exocraft even with this change.
[*]Exocraft [b]Cargo[/b] inventory is [b]0.33x ~ 0.7x[/b] as much as vanilla, and [b]Tech[/b] slots have also been slightly [b]reduced[/b]. However the Pilgrim & Nomad have an additional supercharged tech slot to make up for their small inventory size.
[*]The strength of procedural [b]Exocraft Engine[/b] & [b]Humboldt Drive[/b] upgrade modules follows a [b]smoother progression[/b] from the lower to the higher classes, and Humbodlt Drive max speed bonuses are [b]~1.33x[/b] stronger.
[*]The inventory size of [b]Storage Containers[/b] has been [b]reduced from 50 to 30 slots[/b].
[*]The [b]% chances[/b] for finding [b]S Class[/b] starships/multi-tools in [b]Poor/Average/Wealthy/Outlaw systems[/b] has been changed from [b]0%/1%/2%/5%[/b] to [b]1%/1.5%/2.25%/3.4%[/b] for a more even distribution. Chances for finding [b]C/B/A Class[/b] starships/multi-tools have also been adjusted slightly to progress a little smoother between the different systems levels.
[*]Thanks to an adaptation of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/1518]gMech - Exomech - Mech Improvements﻿ by Gumsk[/url]﻿, the [b]Minotaur Exomech walks twice as fast[/b], handles better, has a [b]bigger/faster jump, [/b]and takes[b] 1.5x as many hits [/b]before having tech damaged when using the AI pilot tech (to offset the more aggressive sentinels in PTSd). However, in order for other Exocrafts to maintain their use for "travelling long distances quickly," the jumpjets on the Minotaur take more than [b]twice as long to recharge[/b].
[*][b]Minotaur Bore[/b] holds [b]~0.9x as much charge[/b], and recharges [b]half as efficiently[/b]. (still more effective than Terrain Manipulator in both respects)
[*]The[b] Minotaur AI Pilot tech[/b] now [b]costs significantly more[/b] Wiring Loom, Quantum Computers, and an Energy-economy trade item to build, to offer "costly" option vs the Trace of Metal mission's "combat" option for getting an AI-piloted Minotaur.
[*]﻿The [b]Crate/Barrel Fabricator[/b] base-building items have their construction [b]recipe costs increased[/b], requiring significantly more Antimatter, as well as an [b]Atlas Seed[/b] item from the [b]beginning/middle[/b] of the [b]Atlas Path[/b] mission line, making them no longer "early-game" items right at the start. The cost to unlock their recipes is also increased.
[*]Thanks to an adaptation of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/1109]ExoSolar's Super Ship Teleporter﻿ by Exosolar & Babscoole[/url]﻿, installing the starship Teleport Receiver tech will increase your [b]starship's inventory interaction range to 800u[/b] instead of just 150u (in-game description updated to note this). This allows your starship to help fill the gap of not having a decked-out Freighter or maxed exosuit early on.
[/list][list]
[*]Thanks to an adaptation of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nomanssky/mods/50]Reduced Launch Cost 2.1﻿ by Lexman6 & maintained by Lo2k[/url]﻿, the base take-off fuel cost for starships is [b]41% fuel[/b] instead of 50% fuel. This means that without any other upgrades installed, installing the "[b]Efficient Thrusters[/b]" tech on any non-Interceptor starship will allow you to make [b]1 additional take-off per refuel.[/b] (In vanilla, only certain starships would gain a benefit from this tech without additional upgrades, or refueling via Uranium).
[*]You can [b]no longer mine rocks, plants, or most other objects[/b] on planet surfaces / underwater with [b]starship weapons [/b](This includes mining [b]Salvageable Scrap[/b] nodes with starship weapons for [b]Corvette modules[/b]). As a side effect, explosions will no longer damage rocks/plants.
[*]A & S Class [b]Scanner upgrades[/b] now always have at [b]least 3 & 4 bonuses[/b] on them, in line with most other kinds of upgrades. In a similar vein, certain "[b]Rusted[/b]" class upgrade modules now have [b]fewer bonuses[/b] on them, in line with other "Rusted" upgrades, and X Class Mining Beam upgrades are more likely to have more bonuses.
[*][b]Supercharging [/b]the [b]Scanner [/b]multi-tool tech now makes it recharge [b]faster [/b]instead of slower, unlike vanilla
[*]All (legal) Trade goods now have [b]stacksizes of 10[/b] instead of 25, so that having lots of inventory space (ideally in a ship for bigger product stacksizes) will be a big benefit if doing bulk trading.
[*]All Illegal Trade goods now have [b]stacksizes of 5[/b] instead of 25,  but are [b]worth 3x[/b] as much as vanilla. (This is because Outlaw Stations only sell illegal goods in small batches of ~2-10, and giving them smaller stacksizes but higher value is [i]roughly [/i]equivalent to increasing the stock available at each station.)
[*]The markup for Illegal Goods in non-Outlaw Systems is now +[b]100% value[/b] instead of +166% value.
[*]In addition to Exosuit Upgrade Charts, Navigation Data is also now [b]only sold in small numbers[/b] in shops, and Space Stations no longer sell large amounts of [b]crafting/trade alloys [/b]such as Aronium.
[*][b]Guild Shop[/b] items have been reworked:
[*] ﻿ ﻿Only some basic supplies at the lowest rank are [b]free[/b]
[*] ﻿ ﻿All other items are either useful or tradable items / upgrade modules at a [b]-20~85%[/b] discount, or items that can't normally be purchased, but at a high price
[*] ﻿ ﻿[b]Donatable [/b]items are now generally either more [b]valuable [/b]or more [b]difficult to acquire[/b], although some of them will grant significantly more "standing" than in vanilla. Notably, the Explorers Guild no longer accept Ancient Bones, but now accept a wider variety of procedural items such as ones found from digging up buried caches / plants, or Crew Manifests etc. from Derelict Freighters
[*]"[b]Standing[/b]" rewards for a [b]race [/b]or [b]Guild [/b]from procedural Space Station or Planetary [b]missions [/b]have been [b]doubled[/b] , and Outlaw Station mission reward standing has been [b]increased 4.5x [/b](other sources of "standing" rewards unchanged, such as space battles, rescuing stranded pilots, dialogue choices with NPCs, etc.)
[*]Amount of "[b]standing[/b]" required to reach each [b]Reputation Rank[/b] for all [b]races, [/b][b]Guilds, or Outlaws [/b]increased [b]3x[/b] (Autophages are unchanged). Alongside the above change, this makes donations to Guilds for "standing" relatively less effective than they are in vanilla.
[*]The price to [b]upgrade[/b] the [b]Class [/b]of [b]Starships [/b]/ [b]Multi-Tools[/b] is [b]reduced[/b] to roughly [b]~75%[/b] of vanilla cost (Multi-Tool upgrade costs reduced a further [b]50%[/b] since they are much cheaper). This is to help them compete with the increased Nanite costs for many other items / services.
[*]The [b]Wonder Projector[/b] and other "fun" objects such as ByteBeat / Racing buildings costs [b]0.5x[/b] as much Salvaged Data to unlock
[*]Purchasing a [b]random chart[/b] now costs [b]20 nanites[/b] instead of 25
[*]The value you receive when trading in a starship for another, or scrapping it at a salvage terminal, is now [b]40%[/b] instead of [b]70%[/b] of the starship's value. This is mainly to offset the overall increased starship price/value with this mod, which might otherwise make salvaging crashed starships too profitable. Even with this reduction, many crashed starships will yield significantly higher profits than vanilla.
[*]Scrapping ships can [b]no longer yield Activated Metals[/b], but instead can potentially yield [b]Tritium[/b], [b]Di-Hydrogen[/b], Gold, or Magnetised Ferrite
[*][b]Starships [/b]are less likely to usually be found with [b]pre-installed Deflector Shield upgrades[/b], but instead a more even mix of various kinds of upgrade modules. Similar change for [b]Multi-Tools[/b] no longer usually having [b]Mining Laser[/b] upgrade modules pre-installed, etc.
[*]NPC Frigates encountered in space have an [b]80% chance[/b] to be purchasable instead of 60%.
[*]You continue to receive the "Easy" version of Frigate Expedition missions (with the lower "Easy" level rewards) up until [b]owning 5 Frigates[/b] instead of 3, to compensate for the increased difficulty of missions.
[*]The # of expeditions required for a Frigate to rank up has had it's [b]spacing reversed[/b]: now fresh low-rank Frigates start off needing 8 expeditions to rank up, and by rank 5 only need 3 expeditions for each rank up. This is try to tip the balance away from low-rank Frigates always being the no-brainer choice to purchase, as now they will be a longer-term investment when for a little extra you could purchase a mid-rank Frigate to start getting powerful right away. Additionally, due to the increased difficulty of Frigate Expeditions, you will likely be completing fewer Expeditions per day initially, further slowing down the growth of fresh Frigates. Buying a "bad" high-rank Frigate early on should be more appealing, as it may allow you to complete more expeditions per day than you otherwise could, and will grow faster than fresh Frigates.
[*]Freighters have [b]+35 Cargo & -6 Tech Inventory slots[/b] maximum capacity compared to the new "Default" of 30 Cargo, 40 Tech, but [b]more initial Cargo[/b] slots and [b]2.2x increased Hyperdrive Range bonuses at Class S[/b] (with larger bonuses at lower Classes for smoother progression), and should be able to reach ~10k ly when maxed out.
[*][b]Black Holes[/b] move you ~[b]3x as far[/b] towards the Galaxy Centre / Core on average, though there is also more variation as well. (Between 16,500ly ~ 28,500ly per jump). This should make reaching the Galaxy Centre without relying on Portals several times faster (doable in under 30 min travel time).
[*] Starship & Living Ship [b]Hyperdrive[/b] [b]upgrade [/b]"[b]Warp Cell Efficiency" bonuses halved[/b]. Notably, the effective bonus on your ship is rounded down to the nearest multiple of 100, so a single Hyperdrive upgrade by itself will not affect your overall Warp Cell Efficiency. 
[*] ﻿ ﻿However, installing an odd number of Hyperdrive upgrades is not always wasted, as with enough Supercharge slot & adjacency bonuses you can push the total bonus up to the next multiple of 100, with the maximum possible Warp Cell Efficiency using 1/4 of the normal fuel amount when using the Hyperdrive.
[*]In order to keep Suspicious Packets costing a high amount of units from Outlaw Stations, and a reasonable amount Tainted Metal from Scrap Dealers, without making them sell for too many units when sold at space stations, most numbers involving Tainted Metal have been tripled (amount reward, price of Scrap Dealer items, amount needed to refine into nanites, stack size). This should keep Tainted Metal at the same value as before, with the side effect of Suspicious Upgrade Modules & Repair Kits being cheaper to buy from Scrap Dealers.
[*]While PTSd generally ignores the Twich/Expedition rewards, the unique expedition reward ships & tool, [b]Golden Vector, Utopia Speeder, Starborn Runner/Phoenix, Iron Vulture, Boundary Herald, Wraith, Atlas Sceptre, [/b]and [b]Pillar of Titan[/b], are now redeemed at [b]Class C[/b] with much [b]smaller[/b] Cargo & Tech inventory and [b]cost 6-8 million units[/b] to buy, in line with normal small starships / Multi-Tools in PTSd. This means the player now has the option to use them with their unique models/abilities without affecting game balance by deleting the free tech that comes with it (and in the case of the [b]Wraith [/b]living ship, not using it to travel to red/green/blue stars before obtaining the matching hyperdrive / standard Living Ship). However if the player wants to redeem them like in vanilla, they can just temporarily set costs to "Free" in the Difficulty Settings to purchase them and upgrade the Class & inventory slots back to normal at a Space Station. The unique multi-tools are handled similarly, although since they cannot be given a price like starships their descriptions suggest trading in any non Pistol/Rifle multi-tool as a cost instead.
[*]In addition, all expedition/Twitch reward starships are now redeemed with the [b]Hyperdrive uncharged[/b], like buying/fidning a regular starship, instead of it coming fully charged
[*]Similar to the above point, there is an optional toggle at the top of ﻿[b][i]PTSd Rewards Remixer.lua[/i][/b] to make all starships & multitools rewarded from Expeditions & Twitch streams come as C Class with small inventories instead of their vanilla Class (set to false by default)
[*]Instead of having both [b]Sentinel Exosuit upgrade modules [/b]and the new [b]Autophage Exosuit upgrade modules[/b] offer the same possible stat bonuses, they have been [b]differentiated[/b]: Now only Sentinel Exosuit upgrades offer [b]Shield & Health bonuses[/b], and only Autophage Exosuit upgrades offer [b]Jetpack & Stamina bonuses[/b]. (This feature can be toggled off at the top of "[b][i]!PTSd Procedural Upgrade Adjustment.lua[/i][/b]") Thus they now lean into separate roles for combat or exploration. The Life Support tank size & regen rate bonuses for both have been reduced to 0.75x effectiveness, as you can "double up" on those now
[*][b]Pre-damaged slots[/b] on [b]crashed starships[/b] or [b]broken non-Sentinel Multi-Tools[/b] (most Multi-Tools including Royals from Sentinel Pillars, but [b]NOT[/b] Sentinel Multi-Tools from Abandoned Camps) now have a [b]75% chance[/b] to also cost some [b]Cadmium/Emeril/Indium[/b] to repair in addition to their normal costs (roughly ~[b]25[/b]%/~[b]25[/b]%/~[b]25[/b]% chance for each metal). They also have a chance to cost an additional [b]1-2 Wiring Looms [/b]and/or [b]2-3 Recycled Circuitry[/b] (purchasable in many shops in PTSd, and as with the Sentinel Multi-Tool broken slots, you will have to enter the full zoomed in "repairing" window to see the actual amount of Recycled Circuitry required to complete repairs). However due to how damaged slots are placed, the actual chances in practice depend on the inventory size of the starship/Multi-Tool, with larger inventories having progressively "worse" chances than smaller inventories, so larger sized inventories have higher chances to require higher amounts, cost, & rarities of components to fix. E.G. A smaller sized Multi-Tool could have damaged slots with ~20% overall chance to require Indium, and the total repair cost could be increased by ~1.5 million units in PTSd, while a larger sized Multi-Tool could have slots with a ~40% overall chance to require Indium, and a total repair cost increased by ~5.5 million units in PTSd. Normally repairing a crashed starship can be far more preferable to buying one if you're not picky about the looks & type, especially with the increased prices in PTSd. This still allows salvaging them for profit or using them yourself, but should make it a bit more difficult & costly to fully repair something right when you get it, and further increase the value of Repair Kits, which can be still used instead of the Indium, etc. (Can be changed in "PTSd Tech + Upgrade + Recipe + Blueprint cost Rebalance.lua" with the various SLOT_DMG entries)
[*][b]Starship Reactor Cores[/b] can no longer be found as rewards from missions or from freighter or defeating Pirate Dreadnoughts. However, now when extracting customisation modules from a starship (e.g. Wings, but not when salvaging into generic scrap), you will [b]also receive a Reactor Core matching the class of the starship[/b]. You can [b]also [/b]now extract Reactor Cores from [b]Shuttles [/b]& [b]Exotic [/b]starships in the same way, although since they cannot be customized instead of customisation modules like Wings you will just receive some generic scrap worth ~[b]300,000[/b] or ~[b]500,000[/b] [b]units[/b], respectively. (Unfortunately this does not work for Interceptors, and fortunately won't be done to Living Ships either)
[*]The [b]purchase price[/b] for [b]B/A/S Class Starship Reactor Cores[/b] is increased [b]~6-8x[/b], to compete with the unit price for buying a small starship to salvage for a Reactor Core. However unlike upgrading the class of a normal starship, you can get up to a -20% discount on the nanite price of Reactor Cores from your Standing with the local race. C-Class Cores have their price reduced to 0.5x instead, since you will already have some from gathering the parts to build a starship in the first place.
[*]The [b]selling price[/b] of most [b]Starship Reactor Cores[/b] is reduced to [b]~0.17x[/b], which works out that selling one yields around ~67% of the nanites you would have gotten by instead scrapping the same class of starship for parts and selling all the upgrade modules.
[*]﻿Maximum [b]discount [/b]at [b]space station tech shops[/b] from high Standing with local race is now [b]-20%[/b] instead of [b]-50%[/b]. 
[*]Reduced the % chance for [b]Cargo Scan Deflector[/b] / [b]Neural Shielding[/b] to scramble a Sentinel / Pirate hostile scan on each attempt from 50% to [b]30%[/b]. However since you can make multiple attempts during each scan(easier if on a hotkey), using it 2-3 times will still have an overall [b]~51%-66%[/b] chance to work by the end.
[*]Exo-Skiff now requires a Nutrient Processor and larger amounts of Salt, Crystal Sulphide to build, and Exo-Skiff cold storage reduced from 60 to 30 slots
[*]Increased the crafting costs for all Fishing Baits, especially for higher grade baits. They all now require increasingly large amounts of either raw or cooked fish, so that you cannot sustainably use the highest quality bait forever without sometimes using lower quality/no bait or Automated Traps to replenish your "bait fish" supply.
[*]Reduced average waiting time between fish bites/catches and to approximately ~0.7x, and reduced the window where you can catch a fish after it bites from ~2 seconds to ~1 second.
[*]Improved the bonuses to fish quality for all kinds of [b]bait [/b](including using food as bait), especially [b]Spicy Chum[/b] and [b]Bionic Lure[/b]. Specialized Baits (Mealworms, Bionic Lure, Dangling Orb, etc.) now also give small improvements to fish size chances, not just fish quality. Weather/Time based baits now give nearly the same rarity boost as Spicy Chum, and should be [b]~1.5x - 2x[/b] as effective at attracting their respective weather/time based fish. ﻿The pattern is that [b]Mealworms [/b]/ [b]Spicy Chum[/b] / [b]Bionic Lure[/b] each increase your average units or nanites profits while fishing by roughly ~[b]1.4x[/b] / ~[b]2.1x[/b] / ~[b]2x[/b] compared to the next lowest tier of bait (or no bait in the case of Mealworms) when considering the units cost of bait. E.G. using Bionic Lure gives roughly double the units or nanites profits compared to Spicy Chum.
[*]Additionally, [b]Diurnal [/b]& [b]Nocturnal [/b]raw fish now have a [b]1.15x[/b] multiplier to their units value, and [b]Storm-only[/b] raw fish have a [b]1.3[/b]x multiplier to give a little incentive to seek out these harder to find fish or use their targeted baits. (Descriptions for the baits for these kinds of fish updated to indicate their increased value)
[*]Added clarification to the in-game [b]descriptions [/b]for the various specialised baits on their relative bonuses to rarity & size, as well as noting the weather/time based baits only work during their relevant weather/time of day.
[*]Slight adjustments to [b]fish size[/b] chance based on [b]sea depth[/b] for smoother transition of Medium size fish appearing and less Small fish in deep waters
[*][b]Greatly increased units value[/b] of raw fish (from [b]5x~12x[/b] vanilla value depending on rarity) to be more competitive with other activities for earning units such as collecting Storm Crystals, Ancient Bones, etc. Raw fish no longer have increased sale value on space stations. Fishing in 90+ depth waters with Spicy Chum can beat the units/minute profits of collecting Gravitino Balls with an upgraded speedy Exocraft, though still a bit below Salvageable Scrap / Ancient Bones (using Bionic Lure instead will roughly double this).
[*]Nanite value for releasing Common (C) & Uncommon (B) fish reduced to [b]~0.33x[/b], Legendary (S) fish nanite value increased [b]2x[/b]. Added clarification to UI that releasing fish yields nanites based on rarity.  
[*][b]Automated Traps[/b] should now take [b]~2 hours[/b] per catch instead of ~1 hour, and can only hold [b]0.5x[/b] as many Common / Uncommon fish per stack. Automated Traps can now be built [b]9x[/b] per planet, but still only [b]3x[/b] per base or nearby cluster. Added to description for Automated Traps to clarify that they will trap fish from various depths regardless of where you place them 
[*]Corrected vanilla issue where Rusted Launcher upgrade modules from fishing had higher Boost Speed 
[*][b]Nutrient Ingestor[/b] effects [b]largely reworked[/b] (with updated in-game description), as with further testing I've discovered that the [b]vanilla version's glitches[/b] still result in preposterously large bonuses when using buffed tech/upgrades in supercharged slots (especially for "multiplicative" stats), regardless of how much I've reduced the food buffs themselves
[*] ﻿Nutrient Ingestor bonuses [b]no longer apply[/b] to all tech / upgrade modules with the relevant stat, but only to ones in [b]supercharged slots[/b] with the relevant stat
[*] ﻿The strength of the bonus is now always ~[b]1.83x[/b] (~[b]+83%[/b]) applied [b]multiplicatively [/b]to the relevant stat within the tech/upgrade module in the supercharged slot, [b]on top of[/b] the usual supercharged slot bonus ([b]regardless [/b]of food quality).
[*] ﻿Most Nutrient Ingestor bonuses to "[b]multiplicative[/b]" stats have been replaced with bonuses  to "[b]additive[/b]" stats that affect something similar, if possible. E.G. The Mining Speed & Resources Mined bonuses have been replaced with a bonus to Exocraft Mining Laser Power, etc. Notably, Breathing Efficiency bonuses are replaced with Exocraft Boost Tank Size bonuses.
[*] ﻿All Nutrient Ingestor buff [b]durations [/b]reduced to [b]0.5x[/b]
[*] ﻿The Nutrient Ingestor also requires [b]Amino Chambers[/b] in place of Lubricant, making it easier to obtain earlier in a playthrough
[*] ﻿﻿While unfortunately this is more restrictive than the vanilla implementation, it offers some interesting choices for supercharging certain techs / upgrades which normally don't benefit as much from being supercharged. It's also nice that it becomes more powerful the more supercharged slots you have access to, and gaining the maximum benefit from it requires you to potentially miss out on supercharging other techs/upgrades you would normally put in the supercharged slots.
[*]The [b]reusable fossil exhibit stations[/b] for assembling other fossils now require [b]50 Polished Stone[/b] instead of 25 Pure Ferrite to build. (Guide entry on assembling fossils now mentions this)
[*]All other types of decorative exhibits & fossils [b]had a hidden cost[/b] of 25 Pure Ferrite to build [b]in vanilla[/b] (even when placing individual bones with no mount), which was not refunded when removing / deleting the exhibit/fossil. Those [b]hidden costs[/b] have been [b]removed[/b].
[*]The special [b]Mud Hut[/b] and [b]Ragged Tent[/b] base building objects can be built on planets outside of player bases as a faster & more convenient method of sheltering from hazards than tunneling underground or creating a roof with the Terrain Editor. In exchange they now have more complex crafting recipes requiring multiple easy to get items such as Marrow Bulbs or Star Silk. This means relying on them requires dedicating some inventory slots to holding their ingredients as a tradeoff. Can be toggled off at the top of [b]gBase Items BasicX.lua.[/b]
[*]The [b]Conflict Scanner[/b] now only requires Quad Servos instead of a Walker Brain to install (Interstellar Scanner similarly now requires Quad Servos)
[*]Various unlisted adjustments to the strength of certain [b]upgrade modules[/b] to make them progress [b]smoother [/b]in strength from Class C to Class S/X and [b]avoid [/b]situations where a higher Class upgrade can roll a weaker bonus than a lower Class upgrade.
[/list][/spoiler]
[b][size=3]Weapon Balance Changes[/size][/b]
[spoiler][list]
[*]Note that as in vanilla, the listed DPS for weapons / multi-tools shown in the inventory menu is [b]not very reliable[/b], e.g. a starship weapon with a lower displayed DPS may actually do far most "real" DPS than one with a higher displayed DPS.
[*]Because core weapon techs typically gain a huge, but unequal boost when supercharged (Usually a +40%~60% improvement to DPS for a maxed out weapon), all core weapon techs have had their attributes divided by the same factor that supercharging multiplies them (this includes the attributes which are better to be low, such as reload time, recoil, or inaccuracy, since supercharging oddly makes those worse by increasing them). Thus [b]most weapon techs start out underpowered[/b], but [b]supercharging them[/b] brings them back up exactly to their "default" strength. In essence, this means PTSd is balanced around the assumption that you are [b]always using core weapon techs on a supercharged slot[/b] as a matter of course, since they gain so much benefit from them.
[*] ﻿ ﻿﻿This is applied to all weapons on multi-tools, starship weapons, exocraft. Also partially applied to all kinds of mining lasers, but only to the damage & heat rate, not the damage tickrate or resource yields
[*] ﻿ ﻿Note: As in Vanilla, while most weapons benefit most from supercharging the core tech, Cyclotron Ballista & Blaze Javelin (charged shots) get more benefit from supercharging an upgrade module instead (Neutron Cannon was "fixed" in PTSd to always benefit from supercharging the core tech by making the charge time improve from supercharging). (Blaze Javelin rapid shots benefit more from supercharging the core tech)
[*] ﻿ ﻿On the flipside, Photon Cannon and Positron Ejector gain huge benefits from supercharging, having only around half their "default" DPS when "fresh" if not supercharged, though slightly less of a gap when "maxed out".
[*]As in Vanilla, most "maxed out" weapons will also have their DPS increase by 1.2x~1.3x when supercharging an upgrade module(if it contains a multiplicative bonus like fire rate), compounding for each upgrade module that is supercharged (Depending on slot placement: often losing adjacency bonuses to move an upgrade module onto a supercharged slot may cancel out some/most of the benefit from supercharging it).
[*]However also like in Vanilla, a few weapons gain very little DPS benefit from supercharging either the core tech or upgrade modules once maxed out(only +~10% for core tech, and much less for upgrades/secondary tech). These are the [b]laser [/b]or [b]explosive [/b]based weapons: [b]Phase Beam/Gazing Eyes, Rockets, Plasma Launcher, Geology Cannon, [/b]and[b] Blaze Javelin[/b]. These may be appealing as "secondary" weapons or in situations where you don't have extra supercharged slots to spare, since you can still get very close to their peak DPS (once maxed out) without having to use a supercharged slot(s) on them.
[*] ﻿ ﻿Blaze Javelin is a special case that actually gets worse DPS when firing charged shots when the core tech is supercharged due to it increasing weapon charge time.
[*] ﻿ ﻿Blaze Javelin also gains very little rapid-fire damage from supercharging the core tech, and also gets little benefit from supercharging upgrade modules either. Because of this, its core tech values were not lowered to compensate for supercharging, since it is rarely worth supercharging at all.
[*]Multi-Tool / Exocraft / Starship weapons only deal [b]0.33x / 0.05x / 0.02x as much damage[/b] to [b]Depot [/b]containers or [b]Doors [/b]to Manufacturing Facilities, to encourage dealing with them on foot. Starship weapons only deal [b]0.2x damage[/b] to freighter cargo pods. [b]Starship weapons[/b] also deal reduced damage vs. [b]Planetary Sentinels[/b] or [b]Walking Buildings[/b].
[*]Most weapons for Multi-Tools, Starships, and the Minotaur have had [b]balance adjustments[/b], mainly to avoid "[b]overpowered[/b]" options:
[*]﻿Most starship weapons have had their [b]cooling rate[/b] reduced to ~[b]0.75x[/b] and [b]overheat cooldown[/b] length increased to[b] ~1.25x [/b](Infra-Knife overheat cooldown increased [b]7x[/b]). Bonuses to heat capacity for most weapon upgrades have been reduced even further.
[*]Various bonuses from upgrades have been adjusted both to ensure all weapons benefit from upgrades to a similar degree, and to prevent all weapons from becoming rapid-fire machine guns when fully upgraded.
[*][b]Starship Weapons[/b]
[*] ﻿ ﻿ ﻿ [b]﻿[/b]Starship weapon effectiveness [b]vs. Torpedoes & Freighter Hulls[/b] have been ﻿adjusted to match their effectiveness against starship Hulls (with an exception of a [b]0.7x reduction for Positron Ejector vs. Freighter Hulls[/b], since Freighters are a much larger target and thus easier to land shots against)
[*] ﻿ ﻿ ﻿ [b]﻿Photon Cannon & Spewing Vents[/b] ﻿ [b]﻿Damage [/b]reduced to [b]0.9x[/b], ﻿﻿[b]Auto Aim[/b] angle range increased [b]1.33x[/b]. ﻿[b]Critical [/b]multiplier is now [b]2x [/b]instead of 1.5x. ﻿[b]Fire rate[/b] lowered to [b]0.6x[/b], but damage increased proportionally to compensate. ﻿Leans more into the "easy to use" role, as the only weapon to be equally effective against Shields or Hulls and is hard to overheat.
[*]﻿ ﻿ ﻿ [b]﻿ ﻿Sentinel Cannon[/b] ﻿ ﻿ ﻿ ﻿ [b]﻿[/b]The Sentinel Cannon starts with about [b]~85%[/b] of the [b]DPS [/b]of the regular Photon Cannon, because its higher fire rate gets more relative benefit from the set damage on Photon Cannon upgrade modules (description now notes this). So once fully maxed out, it should have about [b]~+20% DPS[/b] compared to a Photon Cannon
[*] ﻿ ﻿ ﻿ [b]﻿Positron Ejector ﻿ ﻿Range [/b]reduced to [b]0.7x[/b], ﻿[b]﻿Damage [/b]increased [b]1.05x,[/b] ﻿[b]Dispersion[/b](spread/inaccuracy) increased by [b]2x, ﻿[/b]﻿[b]1.5x [/b]the [b]number of bullets[/b] (each bullet is proportionally weaker to maintain total damage). ﻿[b]A[/b][b]uto Aim[/b] angle range reduced to [b]0.67x[/b]. Just like in vanilla, it still deals [b]100% Hull[/b] damage (70% vs. Freighter Hulls) and [b]33% Shield[/b] damage. ﻿The max bonuses from upgrade modules for Positron Ejector have also been buffed slightly, including damage increased to [b]~1.25x[/b]. It is still quite powerful but now really requires getting to close range and staying there to be effective, where it can quickly destroy most ships.
[*] ﻿ ﻿ ﻿ ﻿[b]Infra Knife ﻿ ﻿[/b] [b]﻿[/b]   Instead of vanilla values, now does [b]120% Hull[/b] damage (110% vs. "Boss" Freighter Hulls) and [b]40% Shield[/b] damage. Now starts with [b]2x[/b] bullets per shot as it did in previous versions, [b]Projectile Speed[/b] increased by [b]1.5x[/b]. ﻿[b]Critical [/b]multiplier is now [b]1.2x [/b]instead of 1.5x. ﻿﻿﻿[b]Fire rate[/b] increased to [b]1.33x[/b], but damage lowered proportionally to compensate.[b]﻿ ﻿[/b]﻿﻿In vanilla (pre-Outlaws) I personally miss the overwhelming majority of all shots with the Infra-Knife, now it should be be easier to hit targets with it, and rewarding enough on a hit that you don't mind still missing a bunch of your shots.
[*] [b]Rockets ﻿ ﻿ ﻿ ﻿[/b]Instead of vanilla values, now does [b]120% Hull[/b] damage and [b]60% Shield[/b] damage. ﻿[b]Damage [/b]increased by [b]1.25x[/b]. ﻿ ﻿[b]Critical [/b]multiplier is now [b]2.5x [/b]instead of 1.5x. ﻿[b]Overheat Cooldown[/b] increased to [b]~3x[/b] as long. ﻿Large Rockets Tube tech now also increases damage by [b]100%[/b], but requires [b]Indium[/b]. ﻿Greater damage and Critical multiplier but longer cooldown makes the choice when to use it more impactful. The improved tech helps it stay useful in the late game.
[*] ﻿ ﻿ ﻿ ﻿[b]Phase Beam & Gazing Eyes ﻿ ﻿[/b] ﻿Instead of vanilla values, now does [b]80% Hull[/b] damage (90% vs. "Boss" Freighter Hulls) and [b]120% Shield[/b] damage.  ﻿[b]Damage[/b] increased to [b]1.4x[/b]. ﻿[b]Leeches Shields[/b] at [b]0.375x[/b] the rate of vanilla. Gazing Eyes upgrade modules give[b] ~0.1[/b] as much [b]bonus leech[/b] effect as vanilla, which still allows it to end up with a much higher shield leech rate than Phase Beam with enough upgrades. Gazing Eyes upgrade modules now can have up to 3 different stat bonuses. Note that like in vanilla, the relative shield leech effect is greater the higher the user's max shield capacity is. E.G. A Hauler gains much more shields per second using a Phase Beam than a Fighter does, since it has larger shields and they get restored on a % basis.
[*] ﻿ ﻿ ﻿ ﻿[b]Cyclotron Ballista[/b] ﻿ ﻿[b]﻿[/b]Instead of vanilla values, now does [b]60% Hull[/b] damage (80% vs. "Boss" Freighter Hulls) and [b]140% Shield[/b] damage.  ﻿ ﻿[b]Damage [/b]lowered to [b]0.9x[/b]. ﻿[b]A[/b][b]uto Aim[/b] angle range reduced to [b]0.8x ﻿Fire rate[/b] lowered to [b]0.2x[/b], but damage increased proportionally to compensate, with a larger projectile. ﻿Now handles more like a slow-firing mortar, and the top choice as an opening weapon as it strips shields and primes enemies for other weapons with its slowdown effect.
[*][b]Multi-Tool Weapons[/b]
[*] ﻿ ﻿ ﻿ ﻿[b]Boltcaster[/b] ﻿ ﻿ ﻿ ﻿[b]Damage[/b] increased ~[b]1.46x[/b] ﻿ ﻿[b]Critical [/b]multiplier is now[b] 1.8x [/b]instead of 1.5x[b]﻿ ﻿ ﻿ ﻿[/b][b]Upgrade Modules[/b] have their bonus [b]Damage [/b]increased [b]4x[/b]. ﻿Also, the special [b]Sentinel Weapon Upgrade[/b] Modules which only work on the Boltcaster [b]no longer[/b] give bonuses to [b]Fire Rate[/b], but their [b]Damage bonuses are ~15x[/b] larger. ﻿It should start out underperforming slightly, but since it is the only Multi-Tool weapon capable of having more than 3 Upgrade Modules it can still eventually become quite powerful, especially if consistently hitting weak points.
